===California Rancheria Termination Act=== {{main|California Rancheria Termination Acts}} Three [[California Rancheria Termination Acts]] (and an amendment) were passed in the 1950s and 1960s. The first Act, passed in 1956, the second in 1957,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zf6ZU2M8NMQC&lpg|title= American Indian Nations from Termination to Restoration, 1953–2006 |first=Roberta |last=Ulrich |publisher=University of Nebraska Press |date=2010| isbn = 978-0-8032-3364-5 | page = 127 |accessdate=2014-12-19}}</ref> and the final act of 1958 targeted 41 Rancherias for termination and an additional 7 under an amendment of 1964.
The first termination occurred on March 29, 1956, for the [[Koi Nation|Koi Nation of the Lower Lake Rancheria]] in two laws, Public Law 443 [H. R. 585] 70 Stat. 58<ref>http://digital.library.okstate.edu/kappler/vol6/html_files/v6p0721.html#p721a</ref> and Public Law 751 [H. R. 11163] 70 Stat. 595 which amended the description of the property.<ref>http://digital.library.okstate.edu/kappler/vol6/html_files/v6p0749.html#p749a</ref> After years of attempting to have their status reaffirmed, the Bureau of Indian Affairs "citing oversights in official records",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://koination.com/history3.htm|title=Koi Nation|publisher=}}</ref> recognized the tribe on December 29, 2000.<ref name="ReferenceF"/>
The second termination occurred on July 10, 1957, when the [[Coyote Valley Band of Pomo Indians]] was displaced with passage of Public Law 85-91 71 Stat. 283 authorizing the sale of the [[Coyote Valley Reservation|Coyote Valley Rancheria]] by the Secretary of the Interior to the Secretary of the Army for the Russian River Basin project to build the Coyote Valley Dam.<ref>http://digital.library.okstate.edu/kappler/vol6/html_files/v6p0782.html#p782a</ref> Like the Koi Nation, this may have been a recording error, as the tribe is a federally recognized entity.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ncsl.org/research/state-tribal-institute/list-of-federal-and-state-recognized-tribes.aspx#State|title=List of Federal and State Recognized Tribes|publisher=}}</ref>
One final Rancheria appears to have been terminated prior to the 1958 Act. According to the Indian Health program records, [[Laguna Rancheria]] was terminated as of February 4, 1958.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://bulk.resource.org/courts.gov/juris/j1762_01.sgml |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-12-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120723100357/http://bulk.resource.org/courts.gov/juris/j1762_01.sgml |archivedate=2012-07-23 |df= }}</ref>
On August 18, 1958, Congress passed the California Rancheria Termination Act, Public Law 85-671 ({{USStat|72|619}}). The act called for the distribution of all 41 [[rancheria]] communal lands and assets to individual tribe members.<ref>''Public Law 85-671, August 18, 1958''. ''Indian Affairs: Laws and Treaties, Vol. VI'' (Washington: Government Printing Office), p. 831 [http://digital.library.okstate.edu/KAPPLER/vol6/html_files/v6p0831.html]</ref> Before the land could be distributed, the act called for a government survey of land on the rancheria. The government was required to improve or construct all roads serving the rancheria, to install or rehabilitate irrigation, sanitation, and domestic water systems, and to exchange land held in trust for the rancheria.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://caselaw.lp.findlaw.com/data2/circs/9th/0417482p.pdf|title=WILLIAMS v. GOVER|work=Findlaw}}</ref> All Indians who received a portion of the assets were ineligible to receive any more federal services rendered to them based on their status as Indians.
In 1964, an amendment to the California Rancheria Termination Act ({{USStat|78|390}}) was enacted, terminating additional rancheria lands. Overall, then, there were three rancherias terminated prior to Public Law 85-671, 41 mentioned in Public Law 85-671, an additional 7 included in the amendment of 1964 and 5 that were never terminated but were listed, correcting the number of California Rancherias terminated from the oft-cited 41 to 46 total terminations.
Many tribes expressed dissatisfaction with termination immediately.<ref name="newspapers.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/26019655/|title=The Fresno Bee The Republican from Fresno, California · Page 40|work=Newspapers.com}}</ref> Federal failures to live up to promised improvements and educational opportunities that were supposed to be part of an agreement to accept termination led eventually to lawsuits calling to reverse terminations.<ref>http://www.standupca.org/court-rulings/california-indian-issues/Jul%2012%2C%201979%20Tillie%20Hardwick%20Complaint%20for%20Declaratory%20injunctive%20relief%20damages.pdf</ref>
The first successful challenge was for the [[Robinson Rancheria]] on March 22, 1977, and it was followed by 5 others: the [[Hopland Rancheria]] was restored on March 29, 1978; the [[Upper Lake Rancheria]] was restored on May 15, 1979; the [[Table Bluff Rancheria]] was restored on September 21, 1981; the [[Big Sandy Rancheria]] was restored on March 28, 1983; and the [[Table Mountain Rancheria]] was restored in June 1983. Each of these decisions only pertained to one reservation.
The success of these suits and frustration with unmet promises caused [[Tillie Hardwick]] in 1979 to consult with California Indian Legal Services, who decided to make a class action case.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mail-archive.com/nativenews@mlists.net/msg03524.html|title=NATIVE_NEWS: In Memory and Respect: Tillie Hardwick helped preserve Indian reservations|author=Ish|date=20 July 1999|publisher=}}</ref> On July 19, 1983, a U.S. District Court in ''Tillie Hardwick, et al. v. United States of America, et al.'' Case #C-79-1710-SW ordered federal recognition of 17 of California's Rancherias.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://indiancountrytodaymedianetwork.com/2004/06/02/picayune-rancheria-wins-latest-round-tillie-hardwick-litigation-93618|title=Picayune Rancheria Wins Latest Round of Tillie Hardwick Litigation|work=Indian Country Today Media Network.com}}</ref> The Hardwick decision restored more terminated tribes than any other single case in California and prompted the majority of the terminated Rancherias to pursue federal restoration.
Of the 46 terminated Rancherias, 31 have been restored; 6 Rancherias are still attempting to restore their federal status.
===Catawba Indian Tribe of South Carolina Termination Act=== {{main|South Carolina v. Catawba Indian Tribe}} On September 21, 1959, Congress passed Public Law No. 86-322, 73 Stat. 592 calling for the termination of the [[Catawba people|Catawba Indian Tribe of South Carolina]].<ref>http://digital.library.okstate.edu/kappler/Vol6/html_files/v6p0890.html</ref> The Bureau of Land Management terminated their trust status on July 2, 1960.<ref name="ReferenceF"/>
After termination in 1959, the [[Catawba people|Catawba]] nation in South Carolina was determined to fight to regain federal recognition. In 1973, the Catawba filed their petition with the [[United States Congress]] for federal recognition. It was not until 20 years later, November 20, 1993, that the land claim settlement with the state of [[South Carolina]] and the federal government finally came to an end.
Based on the Treaty of Nations Ford of 1840, the Catawba agreed to give up claims on land taken from them by the state of South Carolina. In return, the [[Catawba Indian Nation]] received federal recognition and $50 million for economic development, education, social services, and land purchases.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.catawbaindiannation.com/content.php?title=Catawba%20History |title=Catawba History |access-date=2008-10-01 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708123519/http://www.catawbaindiannation.com/content.php?title=Catawba%20History |archive-date=2011-07-08 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> On October 27, 1993, the US Congress enacted Public Law No. 103-116, 107 Stat. 1118, to restore the tribal relationship with the federal government and resolve the land disputes.<ref>http://uscode.house.gov/statviewer.htm?volume=107&page=1118#</ref>
===Ponca Tribe of Nebraska=== On September 5, 1962 Public Law 87–629 76 Stat. 429 was passed terminating the [[Ponca Tribe of Nebraska]].Conditions were similar to other termination agreements, but each tribal member was allotted up to 5 acres of tribal land for personal use as a homesite and the remaining lands were ordered to be sold. One special provision concerned retaining mineral rights to the property by individuals owning at least 25% in the land.<ref>http://uscode.house.gov/statviewer.htm?volume=76&page=429</ref> The Bureau of Land Management confirmed that the federal trust was terminated on October 27, 1966.<ref name="ReferenceF"/>
Fred Leroy, a Ponca and Vietnam veteran, formed the Northern Ponca Restoration Committee<ref>{{cite web|url=http://journalstar.com/news/state-and-regional/nebraska/ponca-tribe-loses-warrior-guardian/article_56c8105b-e551-5a62-aadd-dce261dd1c3f.html|title=Ponca Tribe loses warrior, guardian|author=PETER SALTER / Lincoln Journal Star|work=JournalStar.com}}</ref> in 1986–87 and began lobbying the state of Nebraska for recognition. In 1988 the state recognized the tribe and agreed to endorse them for federal restoration.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.poncatribe-ne.org/History|title=History|publisher=}}</ref> On October 31, 1990, the Ponca Restoration Act was passed by Congress and signed by President George H.W. Bush.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/101/s1747/text|title=Text of S. 1747 (101st): Ponca Restoration Act (Passed Congress/Enrolled Bill version) - GovTrack.us|work=GovTrack.us}}</ref> Concurrent with their restoration, the Bureau of Land Management restored the tribal trust lands of 241.84 acres.<ref name="ReferenceF"/>
===Tiwa Indians of Texas (now known as Ysleta del Sur Pueblo)=== On April 12, 1968, under Public Law 90–287 82 Stat. 93 the United States Congress relinquished all responsibility for the [[Ysleta del Sur Pueblo|Tiwa Indians of Ysleta, Texas]] to the State of Texas. The Tiwa Indians Act specified that tribal members would be ineligible for any services, claims or demands from the United States as Indians.<ref name="uscode.house.gov"/>
Public Law 100-89, 101 STAT. 666 was enacted on August 18, 1987, and restored the federal relationship with the tribe simultaneously with those of the Alabama-Coushatta Tribe. The restoration act renamed the tribe to the Ysleta Del Sur Pueblo,<ref>http://uscode.house.gov/statviewer.htm?volume=101&page=666#</ref> repealed the Tiwa Indians Act, and specifically prohibited all gaming activities prohibited by the laws of the state of Texas.<ref>http://uscode.house.gov/statviewer.htm?volume=101&page=668#</ref>
== Alaskan natives == Because [[Alaska]] was not granted statehood until 1959, Native American issues played out differently there. The discovery of oil in the [[Kenai Peninsula]] and [[Cook Inlet]] regions in 1957, and along the [[Alaska North Slope|North Slope]] in 1968, brought the issue of native land ownership to the forefront of a conflict over state land selection.
In 1936, the [[Indian Reorganization Act]] (IRA) was extended to include the Alaskan natives. As Alaska did not become a state until 1959, the [[Alaskan Natives]] were passed over as termination policy formed in 1953. The fervor for termination faded before Alaskan Natives became subjects of the discussion. Alaskan Natives hurriedly filed land claims with the [[Department of the Interior]] as state land selections and statehood drew closer.
Secretary of the Interior [[Stewart Udall]] was a supporter of the Natives. In 1966, he issued a freeze on state land selections. In 1969 he issued the Deep Freeze, which declared ninety percent of the state off limits to any form of federal land transfer. One of the main bodies responsible for representing the interests of the Alaskan Natives is the Alaska Federation of Natives. From 1966 to 1971, this group lobbied for a fair land claims settlement act, which resulted in the [[Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act]] (ANCSA).<ref>Utter, Jack. ''American Indians: Answers to Today's Questions''. 2. Norman: University of Oklahoma Press, 2001.</ref> ANCSA was intended both to provide the state with land promised in gaining statehood and the Natives with a {{convert|40|e6acre|km2|adj=on}} land base.
This act (43 U.S.C. § 1617) was signed into law by President [[Richard Nixon]] on December 18, 1971. It revoked previous land claims by the Alaskan natives. Initially, the legislation divided the land into twelve regional (a thirteenth would be added later for natives living outside of the state) and 220 local corporations. U.S. citizens with one-fourth (equivalent to one grandparent) or more Alaska Indian, Eskimo, or Aleut blood living when the Act was passed were considered Native American, and were qualified to participate in receiving dividends from oil production. Natives could register with their village or, if they chose not to enroll with their village, could become "at large" shareholders of the regional corporation. (Note: The [[Tsimshian Indians of the Annette Island Reserve of Metlakatla]] had been granted a reserve from Congress after emigrating from Canada; they were exempt from ANCSA.)
Each registered member of the village corporations received 100 shares of stock in the village corporation. The corporations were granted the {{convert|44|e6acre|km2|adj=on}} land base, or about twelve percent of the state of Alaska. In addition, they received around $962.5 million from both federal and state governments, which was distributed over eleven years. The first five years saw 10% of the money received go to the shareholders of the company, and 45% each to the regional and local corporations. Afterward, half of the money was distributed to the regional corporations and half to the village corporations and "at large" shareholders on a per capita basis.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://litsite.alaska.edu/aktraditions/ancsa.html |title=Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act (ANCSA) by Alexandra J. McClanahan |accessdate=2008-10-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080907132246/http://litsite.alaska.edu/aktraditions/ancsa.html |archivedate=September 7, 2008 }}</ref>
===Response and effects=== The land grant came at a cost. Aboriginal title to the land and aboriginal hunting and fishing rights were extinguished by the act in exchange for fee-simple title to the land and monetary grants to the Native corporations. Certain aboriginal rights, including subsistence and medical care, were protected under other laws, including the Nelson Act of 1905, the Snyder Act of 1921, the Health Facilities Act of 1957, the Marine Mammal Protection Act, the Environmental Protection Act, the Indian Self-Determination Act of 1975, and the Indian Health Care Improvement Act of 1976. In addition, the [[Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation Act]] (ANILCA) protected over {{convert|100|e6acre|km2}} of federal lands in Alaska and the subsistence lifestyle of the Alaskan Natives. This act, passed into law in 1980, doubled the size of the country's national park and refuge system. It created 10 new national parks and increased the area of three existing units.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Sherwonit | first1 = Bill | year = 1998 | title = Teaming Up with Alaska's Natives to Save Land and a Way of Life | url = | journal = Natural Resources Journal | volume = 38 | issue = | page = 85 }}</ref> By enacting this law, the government effectively protected land for the Alaskan Natives to continue subsistence living. These laws indicate that the government does not distinguish between tribal nations and the Alaskan Natives.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alaskool.org/projects/ancsa/berger1984/ANRC_Berger.html|title=Berger Launches ANCSA Hearings: Focus on Native Sovereignty, ''Arctic Policy Review''|date=June 1984|accessdate=2008-11-07}}</ref>
A negative aspect of the ANCSA was that any child born after the passage of the ANCSA could receive no shares under the statute, but could become shareholders by inheritance. Shares could also be inherited by non-Natives, putting the Natives in a difficult position in trying to maintain Native control of the corporations. Shares could also be sold after a 20-year period. Sovereignty was extinguished with the ANCSA and all aboriginal rights were subject to state law.<ref name="bloodstruggle"/> The village corporations owned only the surface of the selected land. Minerals located below the surface belonged to the regional corporations.
==Politics== The political climate after World War II based its ideology on building a patriotic, strong, conforming society with all ethnic groups melding together in which free democracy protected American principals of growth through one's own achievement. The Truman administration laid the groundwork for termination, authorizing the [[Indian Claims Commission]] to settle and pay off Indian groups and surveying conditions in Indian country with the Hoover Task Force. The claims and large expenditures for the survey, coupled with high war debt, led the Eisenhower administration to seek ways to retrench federal budgeting and spending.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Weeks|first1=Philip|title="They Made Us Many Promises": The American Indian Experience 1524 to the Present|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=X_NjBAAAQBAJ&lpg|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|accessdate=23 December 2014|pages=199|date=2014}}</ref>
In attempting to grasp what was meant by assimilation into the broader society, understanding the political landscape of the times is important. Assimilation did not mean amalgamation. Cultural diversity was not something to be appreciated, it was a problem that needed to be solved.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Metcalf|first1=R. Warren|title=Termination's Legacy: The Discarded Indians of Utah|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8lvBQBOP3icC&lpg|publisher=University of Nebraska Press|accessdate=23 December 2014|pages=34|format=Book|date=2002}}</ref> This was the United States of "separate but equal". To put the period in historic context, House Concurrent Resolution 108 passed in 1953, [[McCarthyism]] was in full swing and the [[Communist Control Act of 1954]] was designed to keep "collectivism" out of politics. [[Brown v. Board of Education]] was decided in 1954,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/347/483/case.html|title=Brown v. Board of Education of Topeka :: 347 U.S. 483 (1954) :: Justia U.S. Supreme Court Center|work=Justia Law}}</ref> and the US was a decade away from the passage of the [[Civil Rights Act of 1964]]. Anti-miscegenation laws were predominant (see [[Anti-miscegenation laws in the United States]]) and until the [[Perez v. Sharp]] decision of 1948 and [[Loving v. Virginia]] decision of 1967 racial inter-marriage was banned in over 30 states.
Allotment programs of the previous decades had led to surplus lands being sold by the government to allow white settlement on former reservation lands, creating an attitude that reservations were standing in the way of progress for both native peoples and newly arrived whites. In fact, one of the main architects of the termination policy, Senator [[Arthur V. Watkins]]' parents had expanded their farm by purchasing surplus reservation lands from the Uintah and Ouray Reservation.<ref>{{harvnb|Metcalf (2002)|pp=25–26}}</ref> But it was not just land for settlement; reservations were barriers to the government earning revenues from oil leases, mining leases, timber leases and hydroelectric dams. The perception was that the Indians were under-utilizing their resources and blocking the ability of the government to exploit the environment as a revenue base.<ref>{{harvnb|Lewis: Termination of the Grand Ronde (2009)| pp=151–155}}</ref>
Politicians from both Democratic and Republican backgrounds supported termination<ref>{{harvnb|Weeks (2014)|pp=199–200}}</ref><ref name="harvnb|Metcalf 2002|pp=76–78">{{harvnb|Metcalf (2002)|pp=76–78}}</ref> and in truth geographic location may have played a much stronger roll in support than party affiliation. A review of the political figures involved shows a preponderance of supporters were from western states with high Indian populations.<ref>{{harvnb|Lewis: Termination of the Grand Ronde (2009)| pp=170}}</ref> In fact, rather than true opposition to termination, the question was whether termination should be unilaterally applied or whether tribal consent should be obtained. Even those who had a real understanding of native peoples and customs, did not question that they would be terminated, but rather how quickly it should be done, how ready they were, whether Congress should immediately or gradually withdraw its trust obligations—in other words to what degree implementation would occur and when.<ref>{{harvnb|Weeks (2014)|pp=199}}</ref><ref name="harvnb|Metcalf 2002|pp=76–78"/><ref name="Termination and Restoration">{{cite web|url=http://www.oregonencyclopedia.org/articles/termination_and_restoration/#.VJuCuv-oDA|title=Termination and Restoration|publisher=}}</ref>
The native political positions were a little more clearly in favor or opposition. The [[Bureau of Indian Affairs]] had had management issues for decades. Poorly trained personnel, inefficiency, corruption, and lack of consistent policy plagued the organization almost from its founding.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.downsizinggovernment.org/interior/indian-lands-indian-subsidies|title=Indian Lands, Indian Subsidies,|work=Downsizing the Federal Government}}</ref> For some tribes, relief from BIA oversight of policies and funds seemed as if it might pave the way for tribes to maintain their own traditional ways of operating.<ref name="Kidwell (2002)">{{cite journal|last1=Kidwell|first1=Clara Sue|title=The Resurgence of the Choctaws in the Twentieth Century|journal=Indigenous Nations Studies Journal|volume= . 3, No. 1|issue=Spring 2002|pages=10–12|url=http://kuscholarworks.ku.edu/bitstream/handle/1808/5782/ins.v03.n1.3-18.pdf?sequence=1|accessdate=26 December 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.minorityrights.org/2615/united-states-of-america/native-americans.html|title=Minority Rights Group International : United States of America : Native Americans|publisher=|access-date=2014-12-26|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141226024615/http://www.minorityrights.org/2615/united-states-of-america/native-americans.html|archive-date=2014-12-26|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref name="Clements (2009)">{{cite journal|last1=Clements|first1=Chris|title=Federal Termination and Its Effects on the Land, Culture, and Identity of the Klamath Indian Tribe|journal=History Department Rutgers|issue=March 2009|url=http://history.rutgers.edu/honors-papers-2009/148-federal-termination-and-its-effects/file|page=41|accessdate=27 December 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141227053848/http://history.rutgers.edu/honors-papers-2009/148-federal-termination-and-its-effects/file|archivedate=27 December 2014|df=}}</ref><ref name="Philp (1999)">{{cite book|last1=Philp|first1=Kenneth R.|title=Termination revisited : American Indians on the trail to self-determination, 1933-1953|date=1999|publisher=Univ. of Nebraska Press|location=Lincoln [u.a.]|isbn=0-8032-3723-5|pages=171|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=68ggiC4QtRkC&lpg|accessdate=27 December 2014}}</ref> But for the vast majority of tribes, termination meant death – an end to sovereignty, an end to communal life, an end to services like healthcare, utilities, and education.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Tigerman|first1=Kathleen|title=Wisconsin Indian Literature: Anthology of Native Voices|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BTnBMOERCOUC&lpg|publisher=University of Wisconsin Press|accessdate=26 December 2014|pages=34–36|date=2006}}</ref>
===Legislative figures=== Some of the major supporters of the termination movement included political appointees, which clearly illustrate that support was not particularly partisan. Truman's appointee as Commissioner of Indian Affairs, [[Dillon S. Myer]], was a hard-line "Terminationist" as well as an advocate of complete assimilation.<ref>{{harvnb|Weeks (2014)|pp=197–198}}</ref> For example, in implementing the [[Indian Relocation Act of 1956|relocation]] program, Myer targeted school programs mainstreaming mixed-bloods into public schools and allowing only full-bloods to attend reservation schools, forbidding education on Indian cultures.<ref name="Parman (1994)">{{cite web|last1=Parman|first1=Donald Lee|title=Indians and the American West in the Twentieth Century|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OKOP0UHqOEkC&lpg|publisher=Indiana University Press|accessdate=26 December 2014|page=132|date=1994}}</ref> Myers' militaristic style<ref>{{harvnb|Philip (2002)|p=166}}</ref> resulted in calls for his replacement when Eisenhower was elected, culminating in the appointment of [[Glenn L. Emmons]]. Emmons had lived and worked among New Mexico's Indians and while he favored termination, he was a "Protectionist", believing that with a gradual withdrawal of government assistance, native peoples would learn to be self-sufficient. He opposed programs that exploited native vulnerability and failed to take their wishes into consideration.<ref>{{harvnb|Weeks (2014)|pp=198–199}}</ref>
Truman's first Secretary of the Interior [[Julius Krug]] forsook his obligation to preserve Alaskan natives' rights to the [[Tongass National Forest]]. It was widely believed that he had relinquished responsibility to protect the Alaskan natives in favor of corporate timber interests. Though urged to stop passage of the [[Tongass Timber Bill]] and set aside reservation lands, instead the bill was passed (Public Law 385) in 1947. The following year, Krug prepared the ''Krug Indian Land Confiscation Bill'' to put an end to all native land claims in Alaska, but was forced to abandon the measure due to opposition shortly before he resigned.<ref name="Cowger (2001)">{{cite web|last1=Cowger|first1=Thomas W.|title=The National Congress of American Indians: The Founding Years|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zlcxF5HkXPQC&lpg|publisher=University of Nebraska Press|accessdate=December 26, 2014|pages=59–62|date=2001}}</ref> Krug was replaced by [[Oscar L. Chapman]], a "Protectionist" who was a supporter of Bosone's termination amendment requiring tribal assent.<ref>{{harvnb|Metcalf (2002)|p=76}}</ref> Eisenhower's election saw a shift back to a "Terminationist" Secretary of the Interior, with the appointment of [[Douglas McKay]]. McKay, former [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] governor of Oregon, supported termination as a means of fully assimilating the Indians.<ref name="Coalition of Color">{{cite web|author1=Coalition of Communities of Color|author2=Portland State University|title=The Native American Community in Multnomah County: An Unsettling Profile|url=http://www.portlandoregon.gov/oni/article/505489|accessdate=26 December 2014|page=7}}</ref> [[Orme Lewis]], Arizona Republican and Assistant Secretary of the Interior Department, clearly supported termination and was one of the primary officials to meet with Watkins to map out the termination policy.<ref>Wunder (1996), pp. 213–214</ref>
The ranks of "Protectionist" elected officials—who felt that the Tribes should be consulted, policies should move slowly, and termination should occur only when Indians were ready—were small, but powerful. Some of the leaders were Utah Senator [[Reva Beck Bosone]], [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] who introduced House Joint Resolution 490, which allowed termination only with the Indians' consent, on their own terms, as she felt they were capable of managing their own affairs.<ref name="harvnb|Metcalf 2002|pp=76–78"/> Oregon Senator [[Richard L. Neuberger]], [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] and Oregon Representative [[Al Ullman|Albert Ullman]], [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] worked together to delay implementation of the Klamath termination law until hearings with the Indians were held and amendments could be made.<ref name="Termination and Restoration"/>
Montana Senator [[James E. Murray|James Murray]], [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] and Montana Representative [[Lee Metcalf]], [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] strongly opposed ending federal trust status unless the tribes had requested it.<ref>{{harvnb|Weeks (2014)|pp=200}}</ref> and worked on four proposals demanding restoration of the federal responsibility for Indian welfare, education, employment and health care.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://montanawomenshistory.org/sister-providencia-advocate-for-landless-indians/|title=Sister Providencia, Advocate for Landless Indians|work=Women's History Matters}}</ref> New Mexico Senator [[Clinton Presba Anderson|Clinton P. Anderson]], [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] advocated that the views of the tribes should be considered or legislation should not be passed, as did Oregon Senator [[Guy Cordon]], [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Philp|first1=Kenneth R.|title=Termination Revisited: American Indians on the Trail to Self-Determination, 1933-1953|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=68ggiC4QtRkC&lpg|publisher=University of Nebraska Press|accessdate=26 December 2014|pages=162|date=2002}}</ref>
[[File:Arthur Vivian Watkins.jpg|thumb|right|Republican Senator [[Arthur Watkins]] of Utah was the chief Congressional proponent of Indian termination]] The chief Congressional proponent of Indian termination and leader of the "Terminationists" was [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] Senator [[Arthur V. Watkins]] of Utah.<ref name=Grattan-Aiello>{{cite web|last1=Grattan-Aiello|first1=Carolyn|title=Senator Arthur V. Watkins and the Termination of Utah's Southern Paiute Indians|url=http://content.lib.utah.edu/utils/getfile/collection/USHSArchPub/id/6870/filename/6905.pdf|publisher=Utah Historical Quarterly|accessdate=December 26, 2014|page=269}}</ref> He was appointed as chairman of the [[United States Senate Committee on Indian Affairs|Senate Subcommittee on Indian Affairs]] in 1947, shortly after he was elected to the Senate<ref>Metcalf, p. 7</ref> and quickly went to work to free the Indians from their wardship status under the BIA.<ref name="Cramer (2005)">{{cite book|last1=Cramer|first1=Renee Ann|title=Cash, Color, and Colonialism: The Politics of Tribal Acknowledgment|date=2005|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|isbn=0-8061-3671-5|pages=20|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=O_B2hBX1gZEC&lpg |accessdate=29 December 2014}}</ref>
[[William H. Harrison (Wyoming Congressman)|William H. Harrison (Wyoming Republican Congressman)]] met with Watkins on February 27, 1953 to map out the strategy for termination<ref>Wunder (1999), p 213–214</ref> and subsequently introduced House Concurrent Resolution 108 into the House, while [[Henry M. Jackson| Henry M. Jackson (Washington Democratic Senator)]] introduced it into the Senate.<ref>Weeks (2014), p. 200</ref> [[Ellis Yarnal Berry|E.Y. Berry (South Dakota Republican Congressman)]], was the chairman of the [[United States House Committee on Indian Affairs|House Indian Affairs Subcomittee]], the corollary position to Watkin's own chairmanship in the House of Representatives.<ref name="Peroff (2006)">{{cite book|last1=Peroff|first1=Nicholas C.|title=Menominee drums : tribal termination and restoration, 1954-1974|date=2006|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|location=Norman|isbn=0-8061-3777-0|pages=57–59|edition=[Pbk. ed.].|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9iiiCmDGDr4C&lpg|accessdate=30 December 2014}}</ref>
[[Patrick McCarran|Patrick McCarran (Nevada Democratic Senator)]],<ref name="Lewis: Termination of the Grand Ronde (2009)" /> introduced the [[McCarran Amendment]] in 1952 as part of the Department of Justice's Appropriation Act. The Amendment was supposed to simplify Indian water rights by waiving, on a limited basis, the U.S. sovereign immunity for state litigation involving water. Since Native rights are held in the name of the U.S., the Supreme Court ruled in 1971 in the US v. District Court for the County of Eagle and US v. District Court for Water Division No. 5, that their rights are usage rights and not legal title; thus, states can determine whether tribal rights apply or not.<ref name="Deloria (2001)">{{cite book|last1=Deloria Jr.|first1=Vine|last2=Wilkins|first2=David E.|title=Tribes, treaties, and constitutional tribulations|date=2001|publisher=University of Texas press|location=Austin|isbn=0-292-71608-7|page=131|edition=1.|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dBVlwohq6QgC&lpg|accessdate=2 January 2015}}</ref> [[Karl E. Mundt|Karl E. Mundt South Dakota Republican Congressman)]],<ref name=Grattan-Aiello /> believed that unless a permanent solution to Indian claims was offered, "detribalization" would remain out of reach and Native Americans would continue to rely on the government to do what they should be doing for themselves.<ref>Philip, p 25</ref> [[William Langer| William Langer (North Dakota Republican Senator)]], Chairman of the [[United States Senate Committee on Civil Service|Senate Civil Service Committee]] saw dissolution of the BIA as a means to reduce excessive government spending <ref>Metcalf (2002), p 37</ref>
===Tribal figures=== [[File:Ada Deer.jpg|thumb|right|[[Ada Deer]] was not in favor of termination.]] Several tribal leaders played important roles in the process of termination, including [[Choctaw]] Chief [[Harry J. W. Belvin]]. Belvin lobbied heavily for [[Choctaw]] termination, which contributed to the tribe's being one of more than 100 scheduled for termination. The effective date of the policy was pushed back three times, and the termination law was repealed in 1970, after another change in policy. Many of the younger members of the Choctaw tribe opposed termination and got Belvin's attention. By 1970, Belvin had turned from supporting termination to advocating its repeal.<ref>Lambert, Valerie. ''Political Protest, Conflict, and Tribal Nationalism: The Oklahoma Choctaws and the Termination Crisis of 1959–1970''</ref>
[[Ada Deer]] was instrumental in reversing termination. She was a leader in regaining tribal status for the [[Menominee]] tribe. Deer and other [[Menominee]] leaders believed that "only repeal of the termination act, return of the land to its trust status, and full recognition of the tribe and its sovereign authority could right the wrongs against their people and their land".<ref name="bloodstruggle"/> Ada Deer faced strong opposition from House Interior Committee chairman [[Wayne Aspinall]], who had been a long-time supporter of termination. The Menominee bill to reverse termination had to go through his committee. Deer's work paid off when Aspinall was upset in the [[Colorado]] Democratic primary in 1972, and thus lost his committee chair.
In 1973, Congressmen [[Lloyd Meeds]] and [[Manuel Lujan]] held House field hearings. The [[Menominee Restoration Act]] moved quickly through Congress, and President [[Richard Nixon]] signed it into law December 1973. In 1975, the restoration was complete when Secretary of the Interior [[Rogers Morton]] held a ceremony in which he signed the documents that dissolved Menominee Enterprises, Incorporated. He gave all Menominee lands back to the tribe. Ada Deer's work to reverse Menominee termination was successful.<ref name="bloodstruggle"/>
James White worked alongside Ada Deer to help bring about the reversal of termination. White helped found the organization known as Determination of Rights and Unity for Menominee Stockholders (DRUMS) in 1970. Members of DRUMS strongly protested the development of the [[Legend Lake]] project and put up their own candidates for election to Menominee Enterprises, Inc. board of directors. DRUMS succeeded in blocking the planned Legend Lake development and controlled most of the board of MEI by 1972. In addition, White's work with DRUMS helped bring about the reversal of Menominee termination.<ref name="milwaukee_menominee"/>
[[Tillie Hardwick]] was a Pomo Indian woman who was instrumental in reversing the California Indian Rancheria termination policy of the U.S. government. She filed suit on behalf of the [[Pinoleville Pomo Nation|Pinoleville Indian Rancheria]] in 1979 which was modified into a class action lawsuit in 1982. The case, ''Tillie Hardwick, et al. v. United States of America, et al.'' Case #C-79-1710-SW (often cited as Hardwick I) confirmed, as of December 22, 1983, that 17 of the California Rancherias had been wrongfully terminated and reaffirmed their recognition by the federal government. As many of the tribes involved had lost their lands to private parties, an amended Hardwick case was filed in 1986 (often cited as Hardwick II) to partially restore land claims.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.standupca.org/off-reservation-gaming/federal-acknowledgement-process/tribal-groups-in-active-status/nevada-city-rancheria/1-20-10%20Complaint.pdf/view|title=1-20-10 Complaint.pdf|publisher=}}</ref> The Hardwick case affected more tribes than any other case in California and became precedent not only for additional wrongful termination cases, but is cited in nearly every gaming decision for the California tribes.<ref>http://www.ledger-dispatch.com/news/a-look-at-buena-vista-an-th83-8212-guest-commentary-by-butch-cranfordp{{dead link|date=April 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
[[Bill Osceola]] (June 30, 1919 – April 16, 1995)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1995-04-18/news/9504180379_1_james-henry-florence-arnold-pompano-beach/3|title=Paid Obituaries|work=Sun Sentinel}}</ref> participated in both the March 1–2, 1954 and April 6– 7, 1955 Congressional hearings on the [[Seminole Tribe of Florida]]. On April 4, 1955, when the tribe created a board of directors to organize the tribe, he was appointed chairman. Lacking the necessary funds to make repeated trips to Washington, DC and Tallahassee, Florida to argue their case, Osceola came up with a plan to build a rodeo arena on the Dania Reservation as a tourist attraction. He convinced cattlemen in Brighton to commit cattle and got lumber donations from people in Broward County. Opening day at the Rodeo saw 500 spectators and proceeds were used to organize the tribe and gain federal recognition.<ref name="semtribe.com"/> The rodeo that Osceola began in an effort to save his tribe was christened on February 7, 1997 as the Bill Osceola Memorial Rodeo, to honor his memory.<ref>http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-3635297.html</ref>
In February 1954 in hearings before the joint Senate and House Subcommittees on Indian Affairs in Washington DC, two delegations from Kansas were successfully able to thwart termination attempts against the Kansas Tribes. [[Prairie Band of Potawatomi Nation]] tribal chair [[Minnie Evans (Potawatomi leader)|Minnie Evans]], along with [[James Wahbnosah]] and [[John Wahwassuck]]<ref name="Davis (1996)">{{cite book|last1=Mitten|first1=edited by Mary B. Davis; assistant editors, Joan Berman, Mary E. Graham, Lisa A.|title=Native America in the twentieth century : an encyclopedia|date=1996|publisher=Garland Pub.|location=New York|isbn=978-0-8153-2583-3|page=464|edition=[Nachdr.]|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ynd9AwAAQBAJ&lpg|accessdate=2 January 2015}}</ref> and a delegation from the [[Kickapoo Tribe in Kansas]] Tribal Council including members [[Vestana Cadue]], [[Oliver Kahbeah]], and Ralph Simon traveled at their own expense to argue against termination.<ref>Davis (1996), pp. 286–287</ref>
==Effects== During 1953–1964, more than 100 tribes were terminated, approximately {{convert|1365801|acre|km2|0}} of trust land were removed from protected status, and 13,263 Native Americans lost tribal affiliation.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mnisose.org/profiles/ponca.htm |title=Ponca Tribe Of Nebraska: Community Environmental Profile |publisher=Mni Sose Intertribal Water Rights Coalition |accessdate=2007-05-01 }}</ref> As a result of termination, the special federal trustee relationship of the Indians with the federal government ended, they were subjected to state laws, and their lands were converted to private ownership.<ref name="cowcreek_termination"/>
The tribes disapproved of Public Law 280, as they disliked states having jurisdiction without tribal consent. The State governments also disapproved of the law, as they did not want to take on jurisdiction for additional areas without additional funding. Consequently, additional amendments to Public Law 280 were passed to require tribal consent in law enforcement.<ref name="nrcprograms_policy"/> On May 3, 1958, the Inter Tribal Council of California (ITCC) was founded in response to the pressures of termination and other issues.
Many scholars believe that the termination policy had devastating effects on tribal autonomy, culture and economic welfare.<ref name="milwaukee_menominee"/><ref name="walch_terminating">{{cite journal |last =Walch |first =Michael C. |date=July 1983 |title =Terminating the Indian Termination Policy |journal =Stanford Law Review |volume =35 |issue =6 |pages =1181–1215 |doi =10.2307/1228583 |jstor =1228583 |publisher =Stanford Law Review }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://education.uoregon.edu/feature.htm?id=762 |title=Termination: An Oregon Experience |publisher=University of Oregon College of Education |accessdate=2007-05-01 }}</ref> The lands belonging to the Native Americans, rich in resources, were taken over by the federal government. The termination policy had disastrous effects on the [[Menominee]] tribe (located in [[Wisconsin]]) and the [[Klamath people|Klamath]] tribes (located in [[Oregon]]), forcing many members of the tribes onto the public assistance roll.
Termination had a devastating effect on the health care and education of Indians along with the economic stability of tribes. Along with the end of federal control over land came the end of many federal services which included education and health care.<ref name="Canby" />
=== Education === By 1972, termination clearly had affected the tribes' education. There was a 75% dropout rate for the Menominee Tribe, which resulted in a generation of Menominee children who had only a ninth grade education.<ref>[[Nicholas Peroff|Peroff, Nicholas C.]], ''Menominee Drums'', University of Oklahoma Press, 2006 {{ISBN|978-0-8061-3777-3}}</ref> The tribes lost federal support for their schools, and the states were expected to assume the role of educating the Indian children.<ref>Jon Reyhner and Jeanne Eder American Indian Education</ref> The [[Menominee]] children, for example, did not have their own tribal schools any more and were discriminated against within the public schools. The Menominee education program became a part of Joint School District No. 8. Younger children were still able to attend schools close to their homes, but high school students had to travel to either [[Gresham, Wisconsin]], or [[Shawano, Wisconsin|Shawano]] for schooling.<ref name="Ourada">Ourada, Patricia K., ''The Menominee Indians: A History'' (Norman: University of Oklahoma Press, 1979)</ref> All terminated tribes faced new education policies, which gave the children fewer educational opportunities that were not as good as what the whites received.
The idea of termination was to restore complete sovereignty to the United States, and to encourage assimilation into a modern, individualistic society, rather than a savage tribal mentality. In 1966 the [[Keshena]] and [[Neopit]] 3rd and 6th graders' success on the Iowa Test for basic skills was compared to the rest of their school district (Joint School District No. 8). The school district had a composite grade for the 3rd and 6th graders of 82% and 60%, respectively. However, the two schools composed mostly of Indian students had drastically lower scores. Keshena's scores on this same test were about 13% for the 3rd graders and 17% for the 6th graders, while Neopit's were 15% for the 3rd graders and 8% for the 6th graders. From these test scores, it can be seen that education was not improved when termination occurred and the Indians' level of education was nowhere near that of whites in the area.<ref name="93rdCongress">''Menominee Restoration Act'' Hearings before the Subcommittee on Indian Affairs of the Committee on Interior and Insular Affairs House of Representatives, 93rd Congress</ref>
Terminated tribal children struggled to stay in school, and those who did were excluded from programs that paid for higher Indian education. In 1970 the BIA began to make annual grants that gave scholarships to Indians to attend college. This helped the non-terminated tribes, but individuals within terminated tribes were not allowed to apply for these funds. As a result, individuals who were successful and managed to graduate from high school had trouble going to college because they could not apply for scholarship assistance.<ref name="ReportIPRC">''Report on Terminated and Nonfederally Recognized Indians'', American Indian Policy Review Commission<!--publication year, place?--></ref>
=== Health care === The [[Indian Health Service]] provided health care for many Indian tribes, but once a tribe was terminated all tribe members lost their eligibility.<ref name="Canby" /> Many no longer had easy access to hospitals and had no means to get health care. For example, the [[Menominee]] people had no tribal hospitals or clinics. The tribal hospital at [[Keshena]] had to close because it did not meet state standards, and the lack of funds available prevented the county from making improvements. Along with the hospital, the tribal clinic was also closed after termination occurred.<ref>Venables, Robert W. ''American Indian History Five Centuries of Conflict and Coexistence'' (Clear Light Publishers, 2004) {{ISBN|978-1-57416-076-5}}, p. 331</ref> When there was a tuberculosis epidemic, 25% of the people were affected and had no means to get treatment because there was no longer a hospital or a clinic.<ref>Charles Wilkinson<!--which source? There are two by Charles --></ref> The health standards of Indians fell well below those of whites. The Menominee tribe had three times the infant mortality rate as the rest of the state. Dental care was also affected by termination; ninety percent of school age children in the Menominee tribe were in need of dental care, which was no longer provided as a free service since they did not have tribal status.<ref name="Ourada" /> The Western Oregon tribes who were terminated, much like the Menominee tribe, also felt the effects of termination on their health care services. In a 1976 survey, 75% of the Indians in Western Oregon reported needing dental care and 30% were in need of eyeglasses. In addition to affecting adults, schools also reported that the primary problem for Indian children was the need of medical treatment that their parents could not afford.<ref name="ReportIPRC" />
Many Indians relocated off the reservations during termination and also had no access to health care. When they relocated they were given private health care for six months, but then they had none unless they were close to a city with an Indian health care facility. Eventually the [[Bureau of Indian Affairs]] could not provide necessary health services for the many tribes that were terminated, and Congress began reform the Indian health care policy.<ref>[http://www.ihs.gov/Urban/index.cfm?module=dsp_urban_about History of Urban Indian Health Programs], U.S. Dept of Health and Human Services. Retrieved on 2009-05-11.</ref> In 1955, the Indian Health Service was transferred from the administration of the BIA to the [[Public Health Service]], which resulted in an almost immediate improvement in funding, training and services. By 1964 the reforms were leading to progress, as Indian life expectancy rose from 51 years in 1940 to 63.5 years.<ref name="Sturtevant (1988)">{{cite book|editor1-last=Sturtevant|editor1-first=William C.|title=Handbook of North American Indians: History of Indian-White relations, Vol. 4|date=1988|publisher=Smithsonian Institution|isbn=0-16-004583-5|lccn=77017162|pages=77–78|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yQRpEgEzYd4C&lpg|accessdate=29 December 2014}}</ref>
===Economy=== Termination, although not the only cause of Indian poverty, had a significant effect on it. The Menominee tribe proves a strong example of this; although the economy of the Menominee tribe had never flourished, it became even worse after the tribe was terminated. Prior to termination, Menominee income centered around the mill which was built on a community philosophy and tried to employ as many individuals as possible. After termination the mill was run as a business and unemployment rose to between 18 and 28 percent. The mill did generate increased net sales, however; $4,865,000 in 1973 compared to $1,660,700 in 1961. Despite higher sales, the mill's net loss was also much higher in 1973 ($709,000 compared with only a net loss of $108,700 in 1961); this was largely due to the mill's property taxes increasing from $164,000 in 1961 to $607,300 in 1973.<ref name="93rdCongress" /> With no new industry and the new taxes being introduced, 80 percent of the tribal population fell below the poverty line. In the 1960s, they were forced to sell ancestral land and went from having $10 million in a federal reserve to being considered a "pocket of poverty". Welfare costs within the county also increased during the period of termination. In 1963, tribal members were given a total of $49,723 for welfare, but by 1968 the amount had nearly doubled. As termination continued, the struggles only became worse for the tribe.<ref name="Ourada" />
As termination continued, the unemployment rates continued to increase. The Menominee tribe had 800 individuals within the tribe and 220 individuals who were unemployed in June 1968. By June 1973, right before the termination policy ended, the tribe had almost a 40 percent unemployment rate, with only 660 individuals in the tribe and 260 individuals who were unemployed.<ref name="93rdCongress" />
The Menominee Indians experienced high poverty rates from the very beginning of termination, unlike the Klamath Tribe which was able to escape poverty for a brief period. The Klamath tribe had for years been living off timber and revenue from leasing tribal lands. When termination occurred, tribal land was sold and most of the Klamath tribe was considered above the poverty line, because each tribal member gained $40,000 from the sale. While they had escaped poverty briefly, their economy still suffered from termination. Most families quickly spent the money earned from the initial land sale and were forced to sell more land in order obtain food for the family. After just a few years, the Klamath tribe was in the same situation as many other tribes that were terminated.<ref name="ReportIPRC" />

{{Infobox organization | name = Instituto Nacional Electoral | image = Instituto Nacional Electoral logo.svg | alt = | caption = | abbreviation = INE | formation = 1990 (as {{lang|es|Instituto Federal Electoral}})
2014 (as {{lang|es|Instituto Nacional Electoral}}) | extinction = | type = [[Non-governmental organization]] | status = | purpose = Government elections | headquarters = {{lang|es|Av. Viaducto Tlalpan 100|italic=no}}, [[Tlalpan]], Mexico City | location = | coords = | language = Spanish | general = | leader_title = Director | leader_name = {{lang|es|[[Lorenzo Córdova Vianello]]|italic=no}} | key_people = | main_organ = | budget = | num_staff = | num_volunteers = | website = [https://www.ine.mx/ www.ine.mx/] | remarks = | former name = Federal Electoral Institute ({{lang|es|Instituto Federal Electoral}}, IFE) }} {{Politics of Mexico}} The '''Instituto Nacional Electoral''' ('''INE''') (English for ''National Electoral Institute'') (formerly '''Federal Electoral Institute''' ({{lang|es|Instituto Federal Electoral}}, '''IFE''')) is an autonomous, public organization responsible for organizing federal elections in [[Mexico]], that is, those related to the election of the [[president of Mexico|President]] of the [[Mexico|United Mexican States]] and to the election of the members of the [[Chamber of Deputies (Mexico)|Lower]] and [[Senate of the Republic (Mexico)|Upper]] chambers that constitute the [[Congress of the Union]]. The organization's president is {{lang|es|[[Lorenzo Córdova Vianello]]|italic=no}}. ==History== ===1990–2014=== [[File:IFE logo.gif|thumb|150px|IFE former logo, used from 1990 to 2014]] The IFE was formally established on October 11, 1990, as a result of a series of constitutional reforms approved in 1989 and the Federal Code of Electoral Institutions and Procedures (Cofipe), a law passed in August 1990 and currently in force. The legislative branch of the federal government, the national [[List of political parties in Mexico|political parties]], and the general citizenry participate in its composition. Since its creation, the constitutional and legal regulations in this subject matter have experienced further major reforms, which have affected the composition and details of the IFE. The most recent of these reforms, approved in 1996, reinforced the level of independence and autonomy of the IFE by completely dissociating the executive branch from any aspect regarding its membership or functions, and by reserving the vote within all its directive bodies to the councilors, the members that do not have links to any party or to any state power or body. IFE had legal personnel and assets of its own. Its headquarters were located in the [[Mexican Federal District|Federal District]], and it was organized under a decentralized framework that allowed it to exercise its duties throughout the country. As a result of electoral reforms initiated by President [[Enrique Peña Nieto]], the IFE was dissolved on April 4, 2014, and was supplanted by the National Electoral Institute ({{lang-es|Instituto Nacional Electoral}}, INE). ==Political parties and associations== IFE was also charged with the registration, funding and oversight of national political parties (as opposed to local political parties, which are registered by each [[States of Mexico|state's]] Electoral Institute). Rules and guidelines for the registration of national political parties are outlined in the Federal Code of Electoral Institutions and Procedures. In addition, IFE could register [[national political association]]s, which are intended to assist in the development of democratic life and the country's political culture, as well as being intended to create a better informed public opinion. The creation of a national political association is usually regarded as the first step towards the creation of a full-fledged political party. ==Professional Electoral Service== In order to guarantee a professional and specialized performance of its responsibilities, the IFE used a special system of recruitment, selection, training, and evaluation of qualified staff to provide electoral services, especially in its fundamental areas, which are the ones directly linked with the preparation and organization of elections. ==External links== *[https://www.ine.mx/ INE website] *[http://www.trife.org.mx/ Federal Electoral Tribunal website] *[http://curpyrfc.org/ine/ IFE, Now INE] *[http://directorio.ife.org.mx INE directory] {{National election commissions}} [[Category:1990 in Mexico]] [[Category:1990 establishments in Mexico]] [[Category:2014 disestablishments in Mexico]] [[Category:2014 establishments in Mexico]] [[Category:Election commissions|Mexico]] [[Category:Elections in Mexico]]

[[File:Light clay infill.JPG|thumb|Example use of light clay within a timber frame before rendering]]'''Light clay''' (also '''light straw clay''', '''light clay straw''', '''slipstraw''') is a natural building material used to infill between a wooden frame in a [[timber framing|timber framed]] building using a combination of [[clay]] and [[straw]], [[woodchips]] or some other lighter material.
==History== A mixture of clay and straw was used as an infill material for [[timber framing|timber framed]] building from at least the 12th century in Germany and elsewhere in Europe.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.networkearth.org/naturalbuilding/clay.html|title=An Introduction to Traditional and Modern German Clay Building|quote=Building with clay has a long tradition in Germany and other European countries. Framed structures (half-timbered houses) from the 12th century, filled with a mixture of clay and straw fibers, still exist.}}</ref> Renewed interest in traditional building methods developed from the 1980s after which various [[natural building]] architects and builders started promoting the use of light clay.<ref name=art>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=054_i8KdcCAC&pg=PA167&lpg=PA167&dq=%22light+clay%22+natural&source=bl&ots=4VzMTspw_L&sig=QrHVmnQrZZJNMYHs0fG7N6Lr6K8&hl=en&ei=Izy8TaLtJ5CwhQetk8HRBQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&sqi=2&ved=0CFoQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=%22light%20clay%22%20natural&f=false|title=The art of natural building: design, construction, resources|pages=165–170|isbn=978-0-86571-433-5}}</ref>
==Usage== [[File:Light clay mix.JPG|thumb|right|Light clay mixture consisting of clay, water and straw before application]] Local clay, often local subsoil, is mixed into a slurry with water and then combined with straw or wood chip or other similar material. Wood chips can vary in size from [[sawdust]] to chip 5cm in diameter.<ref name=art/> The ratio of clay to other ingredients can be adapted to either increase thermal mass or insulation properties.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=z_Y2AObA-joC&pg=PA250&lpg=PA250&dq=light+clay+natural&source=bl&ots=SvmhvLrYCH&sig=PJh5g60hsMTPX0MrxqqmK-lATBY&hl=en&ei=0z-8Ta2KOMOLhQfa0dTJBQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CFcQ6AEwBTgU#v=onepage&q=light%20clay%20natural&f=false|title=The natural house: a complete guide to healthy, energy-efficient|page=250|isbn=978-1-890132-57-6}}</ref> The mixture is provided with additional structural strength using [[Wattle and daub|wattles]]. When used externally it can be protected with a [[Lime render]] or a clay render.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.earthbuilding.info/gb/03_material/03-3c_building_techniques.htm|title=Earth in non-loadbearing walls}}</ref>

'''Manuel Miguel de Lardizábal y Uribe''' (1744–1820)<ref>{{cite book |title=Carlos IV y la Universidad de Salamanca |last=Peset Reig |first=José Luis |author2=Peset Reig, Mariano |year=1983 |publisher=Consejo Superior de Investigaciones Científicas, Instituto "Arnau de Vilanova" |isbn= |pages=362 }}</ref> was a [[New Spain|Novohispanic]] [[penologist]]<ref>{{cite book |title=Criminal and Citizen in Modern Mexico |last=Buffington |first=Robert |year=2000 |publisher=U of Nebraska Press |isbn=0-8032-1302-6 |pages=90 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8uOwHvg4H0oC |accessdate=2008-06-02}}</ref> who was an academician of the [[Real Academia Española|Real Academia Española de la Lengua]] from 1775 to 1820.<ref>{{cite book |title=Boletín de la Real Academia de la historia |author= |year=1949 |publisher=Real Academia de la historia |isbn= |pages=387 }}</ref> He seems to have been the successor to chair C of his father in law, Academician from 1746 to 1775 [[Francisco Antonio de Angulo]].
King [[Charles III of Spain]] tried in 1764 to bring back a law of 1734 by his father King [[Philip V of Spain]] whereby even thieves operating in Madrid could be tried and executed even if no murder was involved in the thieving. The royal council pointed out to him that either victims or witnesses would default collaboration with Justice by the general popular feeling that the punishment could be disproportionate with people robbing only money, jewels, etc. while saving the lives of the persons being robbed. The King was thus obliged to keep his ideas on public order to himself and/or educated listeners.
Further, lawyer Acevedo published in 1770 a dissertation against torture, as being in conflict with Nature Rights and public decency within the Social Body. The lawyer politician from [[Zaragoza]], [[Manuel de Roda]] y Arrieta, managed to get Charles III and his Royal Council deliberating around changes into the Penal Legislation, whereby capital punishment and/or extensive terms rotting in prisons could better be modified to convicts performing useful works needed by the public interest.
These moves, prior to 1776, where the king and his royal council echoed letters of intent dated 1776 through reflections on the significant works by [[Cesare Beccaria]], brought about the publication in 1782 by Manuel de Lardizábal of his ''Discurso sobre las penas contrahido a las leyes criminales de España para facilitar su reforma''. He cites Frenchman [[Montesquieu]], [[Guillaume-François Le Trosne]], with his ''Réflexions sur la réforme de la legislation universelle'',<ref>[[:fr:Guillaume-François Le Trosne]]</ref> the German [[Samuel von Pufendorf]], the Dutch [[Hugo Grotius]], the Italian Beccaria, and the reflections on the degradation applying torture of the Frenchman [[Joseph Michel Antoine Servan]].

'''Senate Bill 1752''', more commonly known as the '''Military Justice Improvement Act''' ('''MJIA'''), was introduced by U.S. Senator [[Kirsten Gillibrand]] (D-N.Y.) in 2013 as an attempt to reform procedures for determinations to proceed to trial by court-martial for certain offenses under the [[Uniform Code of Military Justice]] and for other purposes. The focus of the bill is to address the way that [[sexual assault in the United States military]] is handled through the military justice system and the [[command hierarchy|chain of command]].<ref>{{cite web|title=S. 1752 - Military Justice Improvement Act of 2013|url=http://beta.congress.gov/bill/113th-congress/senate-bill/1752/text|publisher=Congress.gov}}</ref> The bill has been criticized as potentially leading to a decrease in sexual assault prosecutions and in the protections offered to alleged victims of sexual assault. [https://www.dailysignal.com/2015/06/11/how-gillibrands-military-sexual-assault-legislation-could-hurt-victims/]. Many support an alternative bill championed by Senator Claire McCaskill, D-Missouri. [https://newrepublic.com/article/116899/military-sexual-assault-vote-senator-claire-mccaskill-her-bill]

[[File:The Emblem of Ministry of Justice of Republic of Armenia.jpg|thumb|The Emblem of Ministry of Justice.]] The '''Ministry of Justice of Armenia''' (''Հայաստանի արդարադատության նախարարություն'') is an Armenian government agency which possesses executive authority and executes policies of the [[Government of Armenia]] in sectors that are closely associated with laws and regulations. The ministry oversees the operations of the following agencies:<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gov.am/en/structure/3/|title=Government - Structure - The Government of the Republic of Armenia|last=LLC|first=Helix Consulting|date=|website=www.gov.am|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-06-29}}</ref>
* Compulsory Enforcement Service * Penitentiary Service * Probation Service
The ministry was founded in 1920 under the government of the newly formed [[Armenian Soviet Socialist Republic]].
== History == In 1920, the Revolutionary Committee of the Armenian SSR founded the People's Commissariat of Justice, which began to control the Armenian prosecutor's office in December 1923. The Communist Party of Armenia was in-active from 1930 to 1933, of which during those three years, the justice system of [[Armenia]] was administered by the [[Procurator General of the Soviet Union]] and the [[Supreme Court of the USSR]]. In 1936, the prosecutor's office and the investigative bodies were separated from the People's Court of Justice, and the People's Commissariat was reorganized into the Ministry of Justice. It operated until 1959, when it's functions were exercised by the Supreme Court until the 1970s. By ordee of the Supreme Soviet of the USSR of November 2, 1970, the Ministry of Justice of the Armenian SSR was reestablished and became the precursor to the Ministry of Justice of Armenia which was founded in 1991, following the USSR's demise.
