{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2014}} {{mergefrom|None of the above (India)|discussion=Wikipedia_talk:WikiProject_Elections_and_Referendums#Merging_NOTA_India_to_NOTA|date=November 2018}} {{voting}} "'''None of the above'''", or '''NOTA''' for short, also known as "'''against all'''" or a "'''scratch'''" vote, is a [[ballot]] option in some [[jurisdiction]]s or [[organization]]s, designed to allow the voter to indicate disapproval of the candidates in a [[voting system]]. It is based on the principle that [[consent]] requires the ability to withhold consent in an election, just as they can by voting "No" on [[referendum|ballot questions]].
Entities that include "None of the Above" on ballots as standard procedure include [[India]] ("None of the above"), [[Greece]] (λευκό, white), the [[U.S. state]] of [[Nevada]] ([[None of These Candidates]]), [[Ukraine]] (''Проти всіх'','' "against all"''), [[Spain]] (''voto en blanco'', "white vote"), and [[Colombia]] (''voto en blanco''). [[Russia]] had such an option on its ballots (''Против всех,'' "against all") until it was abolished in 2006.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.angus-reid.com/polls/index.cfm/fuseaction/viewItem/itemID/12773 |title=Russians Divided Over Electoral Reforms: Angus Reid Global Monitor |publisher=Angus-reid.com |date= |accessdate=2015-07-06|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080906002157/http://www.angus-reid.com/polls/index.cfm/fuseaction/viewItem/itemID/12773|archivedate=2008-09-06}}</ref> [[Bangladesh]] introduced this option (''না ভোট''<!---This needs an English translation--->) in 2008.<ref name=bd>{{cite news|title=Bangladesh amends election law incorporating 'no' vote option|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2008-07-14/rest-of-world/27918086_1_general-elections-votes-amendment|accessdate=26 September 2011|newspaper=Times of India|date=Jul 14, 2008}}</ref> Pakistan introduced this option on ballot papers for the [[Pakistani general election, 2013|2013 Pakistan elections]], but the [[Election Commission of Pakistan]] later rejected it.<ref name="tribune">{{cite web |url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/530557/none-of-the-above-vote-to-be-added-to-ballots-ecp/ |title='None of the above' vote to be added to ballots: ECP - The Express Tribune |publisher=Tribune.com.pk |date= |accessdate=2016-05-07}}</ref> Beginning with the [[Bulgarian presidential election, 2016|2016 presidential election]], [[Bulgaria]] introduced a 'none of the above' option, which received 5.59% of the vote in the first round and 4.47% in the run-off.
When "None of the Above" is listed on a ballot, there is the possibility of NOTA receiving a [[majority]] or [[plurality (voting)|plurality]] of the vote, and so "winning" the election. In such a case, a variety of formal procedures may be invoked, including having the office remain vacant, having the office filled by appointment, re-opening [[nomination]]s or holding another election (in a body operating under [[parliamentary procedure]]), or it may have no effect whatsoever, as in India and the US state of Nevada, where the next highest total wins regardless.
==Soviet Union== In the 1990 elections that led to the [[break-up of the Soviet Union]], the Soviet version of "none of above" led to new elections with new candidates in 200 races of the 1,500-seat [[Congress of People's Deputies of Russia|Congress of People's Deputies]].<ref name=JFund /><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.arunachaltimes.in/wordpress/2013/10/09/nota-voting/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-02-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923174514/http://www.arunachaltimes.in/wordpress/2013/10/09/nota-voting/ |archivedate=23 September 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> More than 100 incumbents representing the [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union]] were defeated in the run-off, leading to [[Boris Yeltsin]] to later say the "none of the above" option "helped convince the people they had real power even in a rigged election, and [it] played a role in building true democracy."<ref name=JFund />
==Spain==
===Blank ballot=== Due to the Spanish voting regulations (''[[:es:Legislación electoral española|legislación electoral española]]''), {{es icon}} the blank ballot is recognized as 'none of the above' (''voto en blanco'') but has very little chance to influence the distribution of seats within a democratic election. It is mostly considered as a statistical indicator of candidatures' disapproval. The blank ballots only increase the amount of valid votes, raising the threshold of votes (3% and 5% depending on the election) which every political party has to overcome to be fully considered. The parties over the threshold get their seats according to the [[D'Hondt method]].
===Blank seats (''Escaños en blanco'')=== Since 1999, several political parties<ref>[https://servicio.mir.es/nfrontal/webpartido_politico/partido_politicoDatos.html?nmformacion=2244] {{dead link|date=May 2016}}</ref><ref>[https://servicio.mir.es/nfrontal/webpartido_politico/partido_politicoDatos.html?nmformacion=2403] {{dead link|date=May 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://servicio.mir.es/nfrontal/webpartido_politico.html;jsessionid=FF84718865B5919798D2C716A220398B|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20121218100841/https://servicio.mir.es/nfrontal/webpartido_politico.html;jsessionid=FF84718865B5919798D2C716A220398B|deadurl=yes|title=Registro de Partidos Políticos|author=|date=18 December 2012|archivedate=18 December 2012|website=MIR.es|access-date=28 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://servicio.mir.es/nfrontal/webpartido_politico.html;jsessionid=0523926EC252D8B19A3526ACD78D64B5|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20121218045639/https://servicio.mir.es/nfrontal/webpartido_politico.html;jsessionid=0523926EC252D8B19A3526ACD78D64B5|deadurl=yes|title=Registro de Partidos Políticos|author=|date=18 December 2012|archivedate=18 December 2012|website=MIR.es|access-date=28 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20121019030317/https://servicio.mir.es/nfrontal/webpartido_politico.html|title=Registro de Partidos Políticos|first=Ministerio del|last=Interior|website=webarchive.loc.gov}}</ref> have arisen in order to make visible the 'none of the above' option in the parliaments and force empty seats. "Blank Seats" ran for the Congress and Senate elections of 20 November 2011. Its programme is to leave empty the corresponding assigned seats by not taking full possession of their duties as congressperson, senator, etc. According to law, the seat remains assigned to the elected candidate until the possession act takes place, the elected candidate explicitly refuses or new elections are called. In this way, the political party and its candidates stay free from obligations and are not entitled to receive any money from the public funding scheme for politics.
By voting such option at the local elections in May 2011, the citizens of the villages of Gironella (Barcelona) and Foixà (Girona) were able to reduce the number of politicians in their councils by one and two respectively.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.europapress.es/catalunya/noticia-escons-blanc-dejara-tres-concejalias-vacias-catalunya-20110608174059.html |title=Escons en Blanc dejará tres concejalías vacías en Catalunya |language=es |website=Europapress.es |date=2011-06-08 |accessdate=2016-05-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Empar Moliner |url=http://www.ara.cat/especials/eleccions22m/Escons-Blanc-aconsegueix-consistoris-catalans_0_486551938.html |title=Escons en Blanc aconsegueix que tres cadires quedin buides als consistoris catalans |website=Ara.cat |date=2011-05-24 |accessdate=2016-05-07}}</ref> Overall, citizenship supported Blank Seats at different municipalities, including Barcelona, with 15,582 votes (averaging 1.71% of valid votes).
The [[Ciudadanos En Blanco]] (Citizens for Blank Votes) party aims to give blank ballots the meaning of representing empty seats if the votes indicate so as for any other party, disbanding the party when such law would be approved.
==United States== The origins of the ballot option "None of the Above" in the United States can be traced to when the State of Nevada adopted "[[None of These Candidates]]" as a ballot option in 1976.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/07/10/none-of-the-above-ballot_n_3576469.html|title='None Of The Above' Ballot Option In Nevada Upheld By Federal Appeals Court|date=2015-11-25|access-date=2016-08-22|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151125044018/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/07/10/none-of-the-above-ballot_n_3576469.html |archivedate=25 November 2015 }}</ref> In 1998 in California, citizen proponents of Proposition 23, titled the "None of the Above Act", qualified a new State ballot initiative through circulated petitions submitted to the Secretary of State,<ref>{{cite web|title=None of the Above Act|url=http://repository.uchastings.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1945&context=ca_ballot_inits|website=University of California, Hastings|publisher=UC Hastings|accessdate=24 November 2015}}</ref> but the measure was defeated in the March 2000 general election 64% to 36%.<ref>{{cite web|title=Proposition 23 election results|url=https://ballotpedia.org/California_Proposition_23,_the_%22None_of_the_Above%22_Act_(2000)|website=BallotPedia|accessdate=24 November 2015}}</ref> Were it to be passed by the voters, it was meant to require this new ballot option for all state and federal elective offices, exempting only local judicial races; in determining official election results, the "none of the above" voter tally would be discarded in favor of the candidate with the greatest number of votes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://elections.cdn.sos.ca.gov/ballot-measures/pdf/initiatives-by-title-and-summary-year.pdf |format=PDF |title=INITIATIVES BY TITLE AND SUMMARY YEAR |website=Web.archive.org |accessdate=2016-05-07 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150907193230/http://elections.cdn.sos.ca.gov/ballot-measures/pdf/initiatives-by-title-and-summary-year.pdf |archivedate=7 September 2015 }}</ref>
No similar options were known to have been permitted, much less approved, on any other state levels, least of all the federal level, as of the middle of August 2016.
==India== [[File:NOTA Option Logo.png|thumb|Symbol used with NOTA option on ballot papers and electronic voting machines in India]] {{further|None of the Above in Indian Elections}} The [[Election Commission of India]] told the [[Supreme Court of India|Supreme Court]] in 2009 that it wished to offer the voter a "none of the above" option on ballots, which the government had generally opposed.<ref name=ibn>{{cite web |last=Bagriya |first=Ashok |title=EC suggests 'none of the above' option on the ballot |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/focus/indiaelections/2009/04/2009418114915169787.html |publisher=IBN Live |date= 29 January 2009 |accessdate=23 April 2011}}</ref> The [[People's Union for Civil Liberties]], a [[non-governmental organisation]], filed a [[public-interest litigation (India)|public-interest litigation]] statement in support of this.<ref>{{cite news|last=Sorabjee|first=Soli J.|title=Right of negative voting|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/right-of-negative-voting/429335/|accessdate=27 September 2013|newspaper=The Indian Express|date=1 March 2009}}</ref>
On 27 September 2013, the [[Supreme Court of India]] ruled that the right to register a "none of the above" vote in elections should apply, and ordered the Election Commission to provide such a button in the electronic [[voting machine]]s, noting that it would increase participation.<ref>{{cite news|title=India voters get right to reject election candidates|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-india-24294995|accessdate=27 September 2013|newspaper=BBC News|date=27 September 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=SC's landmark judgement: Voters get right to reject|url=http://www.deccanchronicle.com/130927/news-current-affairs/article/scs-landmark-judgement-voters-get-right-reject|accessdate=27 September 2013|newspaper=Deccan Chronicle|date=27 September 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Voter has right to negative voting: SC|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/voter-has-right-to-negative-voting-sc/article5174414.ece?homepage=true|accessdate=27 September 2013|newspaper=The Hindu|date=27 September 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |publisher=Times of India |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Will-implement-voters-right-to-reject-candidates-straight-away-Election-Commission/articleshow/23169193.cms |title=Will implement voters' right to reject candidates straight away: Election Commission |first=Bharti |last=Jain |date=27 September 2013 |accessdate=2013-09-27}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |publisher=Hindustan Times |date=27 September 2013 |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/specials/coverage/MyIndia-MyVote/Chunk-HT-UI-MyIndiaMyVote-TopStories/Voters-have-right-to-reject-poll-panel-must-give-them-option-says-Supreme-Court/SP-Article10-1127779.aspx |title=Voters have right to reject, poll panel must give them option, says Supreme Court |accessdate=2013-09-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130927071428/http://www.hindustantimes.com/specials/coverage/MyIndia-MyVote/Chunk-HT-UI-MyIndiaMyVote-TopStories/Voters-have-right-to-reject-poll-panel-must-give-them-option-says-Supreme-Court/SP-Article10-1127779.aspx |archivedate=27 September 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
The Election Commission also clarified that even though votes cast as NOTA are counted, they are considered as invalid votes so they will not change the outcome of the election process. They are not taken into account for calculating the total valid votes and will not be considered for determining the forfeiture of [[Deposit (politics)|deposit]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Clarification on 'None of the above - counting of votes - reg. |url=http://eci.nic.in/eci_main1/current/ImpIns07122013.pdf |publisher=Election Commission of India |accessdate=19 May 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140209062210/http://eci.nic.in/eci_main1/current/ImpIns07122013.pdf |archivedate=9 February 2014 |date=7 December 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://eci.nic.in/eci_main1/current/PN_28102013.pdf |format=PDF |title=Election Commission of India : Supreme Court's judgement for "None of the Above" option on EVM – clarification |website=Eci.nic.in |accessdate=2016-05-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://eci.nic.in/eci_main/ElectoralLaws/OrdersNotifications/NOTA_11102013.pdf |format=PDF |title=Election Commission of India : Provision for "None of the above" option on the EVM/Ballot Paper- Instructions |website=Eci.nic.in |accessdate=2016-05-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/politics-and-nation/will-implement-voters-right-to-reject-candidates-straight-away-election-commission/articleshow/23171880.cms |publisher=The Economic Times |title=Will implement voters' right to reject candidates straight away: Election Commission |first=Bharti |last=Jain |date=27 September 2013 |accessdate=27 September 2013}}</ref>
In the [[Indian general election, 2014|2014 general election]], NOTA polled 1.1% of the votes,<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/home/lok-sabha-elections-2014/news/Election-results-NOTA-garners-1-1-of-countrys-total-vote-share/articleshow/35222378.cms |title=Election results: NOTA garners 1.1% of country's total vote share - Times of India |publisher=Timesofindia.indiatimes.com |date=2014-05-17 |accessdate=2016-05-07}}</ref> counting to over 6,000,000.<ref>{{cite news |title=Over 60 lakh NOTA votes polled |url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/over-60-lakh-nota-votes-polled/article6017631.ece |newspaper=The Hindu |location=New Delhi |date=17 May 2014 |accessdate=7 June 2014}}</ref>
The specific symbol for NOTA, a ballot paper with a black cross across it, was introduced on 18 September 2015. The symbol is designed by [[National Institute of Design]], [[Ahmedabad]].<ref name="dna 2015">{{cite web |title=Now, 'NOTA' has an electoral symbol too |website=dna |date=18 September 2015 |url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report-now-nota-has-a-political-symbol-too-2126476 |accessdate=18 September 2015}}</ref><ref name="Jain 2015">{{cite web |last=Jain |first=Bharti |title='None of the Above' option on EVMS to carry its own symbol from Bihar polls |website=The Times of India |date=18 September 2015 |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/None-of-the-Above-option-on-EVMS-to-carry-its-own-symbol-from-Bihar-polls/articleshow/49017516.cms |accessdate=18 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Cross-mark-is-now-NOTA-symbol/articleshow/49030054.cms |title=Cross mark is now NOTA symbol - Times of India |publisher=Timesofindia.indiatimes.com |date=2015-09-20 |accessdate=2016-05-07}}</ref>
==Indonesia== [[File:Tangerang Sample Ballot 2018.jpg|A sample ballot for the uncontested 2018 mayoral elections in [[Tangerang]].|thumb]] The Indonesian Law 10 of 2016 regulates local elections, and includes provisions for elections in which there is only one candidate. In such cases, the candidate contests the election against a NOTA option (commonly referred to as ''kotak kosong''/empty box), and is declared the winner if they manage to secure a majority of the valid votes. Otherwise, the election will be postponed to the next occurrence; the government of Indonesia appoints an acting office holder until the new election, in which the losing candidate is eligible to stand again.<ref>{{cite web|title=UU Nomor 10 Tahun 2016|url=http://www.mahkamahkonstitusi.go.id/public/content/jdih/UU_Nomor_10_Tahun_2016.pdf|publisher=Constitutional Court of Indonesia|accessdate=4 May 2018|page=26|language=id|quote=KPU Provinsi atau KPU Kabupaten/Kota menetapkan pasangan calon terpilih pada Pemilihan 1 (satu) pasangan calon sebagaimana dimaksud dalam Pasal 54C, jika mendapatkan suara lebih dari 50% (lima puluh persen) dari suara sah.}}</ref>
There were 3 uncontested seats in the [[Indonesian local elections, 2015|2015 local elections]], nine in the [[Indonesian local elections, 2017|2017 local elections]],<ref>{{cite news|last1=Tamang|first1=Leena Rikkilä|title=Five things you may not know about Indonesia's Regional Elections|url=https://www.idea.int/news-media/news/five-things-you-may-not-know-about-indonesias-regional-elections|accessdate=4 May 2018|work=Institute for Democracy and Electoral Assistance|date=14 February 2017}}</ref> and at least 13 in the [[Indonesian local elections, 2018|2018 local elections]] (including the mayoral elections for [[Tangerang]] and [[Makassar]]).<ref>{{cite news|last1=Juliawanti|first1=Linda|title=Pilkada 2018: Apa yang Terjadi Jika Paslon Tunggal Kalah Melawan Kotak Kosong?|url=https://news.idntimes.com/indonesia/linda/pilkada-2018-apa-yang-terjadi-jika-paslon-tunggal-kalah-melawan-kotak-kosong-1|accessdate=4 May 2018|work=IDNTimes|date=6 March 2018|language=id}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Cipto|first1=Hendra|title=Calon Petahana Gugur di MA, Pilkada Makassar Lawan Kotak Kosong - Kompas.com|url=https://regional.kompas.com/read/2018/04/26/17362571/calon-petahana-gugur-di-ma-pilkada-makassar-lawan-kotak-kosong|accessdate=4 May 2018|work=KOMPAS|date=26 April 2018|language=id}}</ref> In the [[Makassar mayoral election, 2018|2018 election for mayor of Makassar]], the NOTA option received over 300,000 votes, 35,000 more than the sole candidate, forcing a repeat election in 2020.<ref>{{cite news |title=Makassar to rerun election in 2020 after blank box victory |url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2018/07/09/makassar-to-rerun-election-in-2020-after-blank-box-victory.html |accessdate=16 July 2018 |work=The Jakarta Post |date=9 July 2018 |language=en}}</ref>
==United Kingdom== UK electoral counting procedures require that all votes be counted and announced, including 'rejected' votes. 'Rejected votes' are classified into four categories,<ref>{{cite web|title=UK Electoral Commission guide on 'Dealing with doubtful ballot papers'|url=http://www.electoralcommission.org.uk/__data/assets/pdf_file/0012/87699/UKPE-doubtfuls-booklet.pdf}}</ref> protest votes are recorded with others rejected as 'voter's intention uncertain'.
===NOTA UK=== NOTA UK is a voluntary organisation set up in 2010 to campaign for a formal None Of The Above (NOTA) option to be added to ballot papers for all future UK elections. It has made numerous written evidence submissions<ref>{{cite web|url=http://data.parliament.uk/writtenevidence/committeeevidence.svc/evidencedocument/political-and-constitutional-reform-committee/consultation-on-a-new-magna-carta/written/15588.html |title=Written evidence submitted by NOTA UK (AMC 49) |website=Data.parliament.uk |date= |accessdate=2016-05-07}}</ref> to the parliamentary Political & Constitutional Reform Committee (PCRC)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.parliament.uk/business/committees/committees-a-z/commons-select/political-and-constitutional-reform-committee/inquiries/ |title=Political and Constitutional Reform Committee - Inquiries - UK Parliament |website=Parliament.uk |date=2010-07-01 |accessdate=2016-05-07}}</ref> making the case for NOTA 'with teeth' i.e.: formalised consequences for the election result in the event of a NOTA 'win' (as opposed to 'faux' NOTA, whereby the next placed candidate takes office anyway as happens in India and elsewhere). As a result of these representations, the PCRC explicitly recommended in its final report on 'voter engagement', published February 2015,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nota-uk.org/2015/02/05/the-nota-campaign-gets-a-massive-boost-from-parliamentary-select-committee |title=NOTA campaign gets massive boost from parliamentary select committee! | None of the Above UK |website=Nota-uk.org |date=2015-02-05 |accessdate=2016-05-07}}</ref> that the next UK government should hold a public consultation before May 2016 solely on inclusion of NOTA on UK ballot papers. This in turn has led to increased support for and awareness of NOTA UK's campaign and its founder, recording artist and music producer [[Jamie Stanley]] (aka: Mailman), being asked to give a number of media interviews.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QdiG9tCq-BU |title=None of the above campaign is 'essential to the concept of democracy' - Jamie Stanley |publisher=YouTube |date=2015-02-16 |accessdate=2016-05-07}}</ref> No public consultation materialised as the incoming Conservative government scrapped the PCRC, effectively disregarding all of its recommendations.
Since 2015, in part thanks to NOTA UK's lobbying, it has been a Green Party of England and Wales policy to get a form of NOTA (RON - Re-Open Nominations) on UK ballot papers.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://nota-uk.org/2015/11/24/getting-nota-ron-on-all-uk-ballot-papers-now-official-green-party-policy/|title=Getting NOTA on UK ballot papers now official Green Party policy!|author=|date=24 November 2015|website=NOTA-UK.org|access-date=28 May 2017}}</ref> In the run-up to the 2017 UK general election, NOTA UK wrote to the Green party suggesting that they should reword the policy so that, instead of RON, it refers specifically to the more self-explanatory NOTA, and that they should also place the policy centre stage in their next manifesto.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://nota-uk.org/2017/04/29/open-letter-to-the-green-party-re-ge-2017/|title=Open Letter to the Green Party re: GE 2017|author=|date=29 April 2017|website=NOTA-UK.org|access-date=28 May 2017}}</ref>
===Above and Beyond=== [[File:Above and Beyond Party logo.jpg|thumb|right|The party's logo]] The '''Above and Beyond Party''' was founded in 2015 and fielded eight candidates in the [[United Kingdom general election, 2015|2015 general election]], none of whom were elected. Their sole stated policy was to introduce a "none of the above" option on all UK ballot papers.<ref>{{cite web|title=How we intend to force none of the above on to all ballot papers |url=http://www.voteaboveandbeyond.org/manifestolong-term-strategy.html |publisher=Above and Beyond Party |accessdate=24 March 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150330030914/http://www.voteaboveandbeyond.org/manifestolong-term-strategy.html |archivedate=30 March 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Why we must change our political system|url=http://www.voteaboveandbeyond.org/why-politics-must-change.html|publisher=Above & Beyond|access-date=19 October 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151226135840/http://www.voteaboveandbeyond.org/why-politics-must-change.html|archivedate=26 December 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The party's logo is based on the West African [[Adinkra symbol]] "Aya", "derived from a fern tree which famously grows in difficult-to-survive places", and a symbol of resilience.<ref>{{cite web|title=About our party logo|url=http://www.voteaboveandbeyond.org/about-our-party-logo.html|publisher=Above and Beyond Party|accessdate=25 March 2015}}</ref> Critics pointed out that their website and Facebook page at the time indicated that they had policy ideas and a political agenda beyond the single issue of NOTA and appeared to be jumping on the bandwagon of other NOTA campaigns.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://nota-uk.org/2014/12/10/open-letter-to-mark-flanagan-notavote-the-nota-party-the-above-beyond-party/|title=Open Letter to Mark Flanagan (Notavote / The NOTA Party / The Above & Beyond Party)|author=|date=10 December 2014|website=NOTA-UK.org|access-date=28 May 2017}}</ref>
====Inception and officers==== The party registered with the [[Electoral Commission (United Kingdom)|Electoral Commission]] on 18 March 2015. The Electoral Commission listed the party leader, nominating officer and campaigns officer as Mark Flanagan and the treasurer was Karen Stanley.<ref name="PP2551">{{cite web|url=http://search.electoralcommission.org.uk/English/Registrations/PP2551|title=Registration Summary: The Above and Beyond Party|date=|website=|publisher=Electoral Commission|accessdate=5 June 2017}}</ref> The party chairman was Michael Ross.<ref>{{cite web|title=View from the Chair|url=http://www.voteaboveandbeyond.org/view-from-the-chair|publisher=Above and Beyond Party|accessdate=3 April 2015}}</ref> The party was de-registered by the Electoral Commission on 3 November 2016.<ref name="PP2551" />
====Electoral history==== Above and Beyond fielded four candidates in the [[United Kingdom general election, 2015|2015 general election]]. The candidates stood in [[Clwyd West (UK Parliament constituency)|Clwyd West]], [[Cheadle (UK Parliament constituency)|Cheadle]], [[Sheffield Central (UK Parliament constituency)|Sheffield Central]] and [[Leeds North West (UK Parliament constituency)|Leeds North West]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Our eight target seats|url=http://www.voteaboveandbeyond.org/our-eight-target-seats.html|publisher=Above and Beyond Party|accessdate=24 March 2015}}</ref> In [[Sheffield Hallam (UK Parliament constituency)|Sheffield Hallam]] the party endorsed Carlton Reeve, an independent candidate.<ref>{{cite web|title=Our 2015 General Election candidates |url=http://www.voteaboveandbeyond.org/our-candidates-so-far.html |publisher=Above and Beyond Party |accessdate=24 March 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150222180418/http://www.voteaboveandbeyond.org/our-candidates-so-far.html |archivedate=22 February 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Sheffield election candidate to be one of youngest|url=http://www.thestar.co.uk/news/sheffield-election-candidate-to-be-one-of-youngest-1-7100855|accessdate=24 March 2015|work=[[Sheffield Star|The Star]]|date=11 February 2015}}</ref> No Above and Beyond candidate received 5% or more of the votes cast, therefore all lost their [[deposit (politics)#United Kingdom|deposit]].
====Finance==== The party raised funds partially through "AboveBeyond" music nights.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Greenhalf|first1=Jim|title=Musicians set to bring political message to the stage|url=http://www.thetelegraphandargus.co.uk/leisure/tamusic/11808902.Musicians_set_to_bring_political_message_to_the_stage/|accessdate=24 March 2015|work=[[Telegraph & Argus]]|date=20 February 2015}}</ref>
===No Candidate Deserves My Vote! party=== [[No Candidate Deserves My Vote!]] was registered as a political party with the UK Electoral Commission on 23 November 2000.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://registers.electoralcommission.org.uk/regulatory-issues/regpoliticalparties.cfm?frmGB=1&frmPartyID=167&frmType=partydetail |work=Electoral Commission |title=No Candidate Deserves My Vote! |access-date=9 March 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100416164111/http://registers.electoralcommission.org.uk/regulatory-issues/regpoliticalparties.cfm?frmGB=1&frmPartyID=167&frmType=partydetail |archivedate=16 April 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The No Candidate Deserves My Vote party's single objective is to introduce a bill to Parliament to have a "none of the above" option added to every local and general election ballot paper of the future. They feel this will allow the UK electorate to exercise their democratic right to vote to say that none of the parties currently represents them, which will encourage their democratic responsibility to turn out to vote. If a candidate wins an election it is the intention to stay as a [[Member of Parliament]] until the change in the law is enacted. Only then will the candidate step down and the party be disbanded.
It is the intention of the party that, if a NOTA gains the majority vote, it should cause an automatic [[by-election]], the idea being that the majority will have given a [[Vote of No Confidence]] in the candidates. If the same candidates stand under the same policies, then the electorate simply votes NOTA until the candidates change their policies to something that the electorate can vote for.
In 2010, Stephen Phillips of [[Stevenage]] ran for the [[United Kingdom general election, 2010|UK general election]] on behalf of No Candidate Deserves My Vote.<ref>[http://www.steveofstevenage.org.uk ]{{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100323011710/http://www.steveofstevenage.org.uk/ |date=23 March 2010 }} Steve of Stevenage</ref> Phillips received 327 votes, or 0.7% of the vote, placing 7th out of 9 candidates.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/shared/election2010/results/constituency/e43.stm |title=Election 2010 | Constituency | Stevenage |publisher=BBC News |date=1970-01-01 |accessdate=2016-05-07}}</ref>
===NOTA party=== The NOTA Party, in recent years also known as Notavote, was registered as a political party with the UK Electoral Commission on 2 March 2009.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://registers.electoralcommission.org.uk/regulatory-issues/regpoliticalparties.cfm?frmGB=1&frmPartyID=867&frmType=partydetail |work=Electoral Commission |title=NOTA |accessdate=2009-07-08 }}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> It was the intention of the NOTA party to field candidates in every UK parliamentary constituency. The respective NOTA candidates would not have continued in office had they received the most votes, this was merely a mechanism to simulate the recording of a formal NOTA vote. The party was registered as 'NOTA' and not 'None of the Above' as the latter is a prohibited expression regarding registration as a party name.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.legislation.gov.uk/uksi/2005/147/made |title=Registration of Political Parties (Prohibited Words and Expressions) (Amendment) Order 2005 |website=Legislation.gov.uk |accessdate=2016-05-07}}</ref> A subsequent attempt to re-register the NOTA party in 2014 was blocked by the Electoral Commission<ref>{{cite web|url=http://notauk.org/2014/11/08/nota-banned-as-party-name-by-electoral-commission/ |title='NOTA' banned as party name by Electoral Commission | None of the Above UK |website=Notauk.org |date=2014-11-08 |accessdate=2016-05-07}}</ref> on the grounds that the acronym 'NOTA' is as good as the phrase 'None of the Above', the logic being that it would confuse voters into thinking it is possible to cast a formal vote for 'None of the Above' when they would in fact just be voting for another party, albeit one standing on a single issue NOTA platform.
===Zero, None Of the Above=== None Of The Above Zero was a candidate at the [[United Kingdom general election, 2010|2010 general election]] in [[Filton and Bradley Stoke (UK Parliament constituency)|Filton and Bradley Stoke]].<ref>{{cite journal |accessdate=7 May 2010 |title=Filton and Bradley Stoke |url=http://ukpollingreport.co.uk/guide/seat-profiles/filtonandbradleystoke |publisher=UK Polling Report }}</ref> Previously known as Eric Mutch, he changed his name by deed poll to stand under that name. As candidates are listed by surname first he appeared on the ballot paper as "Zero, None Of The Above",<ref>{{cite journal |date = 7 April 2010 |place = [[Bristol]] |title = None of the above, says name-change Bristol candidate |url = http://www.thisisbristol.co.uk/news/says-change-Bristol-candidate/article-1979014-detail/article.html |accessdate = 7 May 2010 |publisher = [[Bristol Evening Post]] |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100412003636/http://www.thisisbristol.co.uk/news/says-change-Bristol-candidate/article-1979014-detail/article.html |archivedate = 12 April 2010 |df = dmy-all }}</ref> in effect giving voters a none of the above option since had he been elected he would have resigned immediately.<ref>{{cite journal |date=11 April 2010 |place=[[Bristol]] |url=http://www.bradleystokejournal.co.uk/plus/2010/04/11/none-above-stand-filton-bradley-stoke-election/ |title=Mr 'None of the Above' Zero set to stand in Filton and Bradley Stoke |accessdate=7 May 2010 |publisher=The Bradley Stoke Journal }}</ref> He came last with 172 votes.<ref>{{cite journal |date=10 May 2010 |title=As it happened: Bristol Election 2010 |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/local/bristol/hi/people_and_places/newsid_8651000/8651796.stm |publisher=BBC |first=Kate |last=Wakefield}}</ref>
===Others=== In the [[United Kingdom general election, 2010|British parliamentary elections of 2010]], a former boxer changed his name by [[deed poll]] from [[Terry Marsh (boxer)|Terry Marsh]] to "None Of The Above X", in order to run as a parliamentary candidate under that name in the constituency of [[South Basildon and East Thurrock (UK Parliament constituency)|South Basildon and East Thurrock]]. Claiming that he will not take the seat if he wins, he told BBC Essex: "I don't take it for one moment that it would be a vote for me. [..] I'm doing what I think the Electoral Commission should be doing and what should be on every ballot paper in any electoral process." BBC News reported that, while the Registration of Political Parties (Prohibited Words and Expressions) (Amendment) Order 2005 stipulates that no political party can be registered in the UK under the name "None of the Above", there is no legislation against a person changing their name by deed poll and appearing on the ballot paper as "None Of the Above".<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/england/essex/8639348.stm Basildon boxer to fight election as 'None Of The Above'], BBC News, (27 April 2010)</ref> In the event he polled 0.3% of the vote, the lowest of any candidate standing.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/shared/election2010/results/constituency/e08.stm |work=BBC News |title=BBC NEWS – Election 2010 – Basildon South & Thurrock East}}</ref> * Another individual changed his name by deed poll to ''None Of The Above'' in order to stand as a candidate in [[Chingford and Woodford Green (UK Parliament constituency)|Chingford and Woodford Green]] in 2010. With the surname ''Above'', he was listed first on the ballot paper in alphabetical order, with all the other candidates listed below. * The [[South Wales]] Anarchists group has run a campaign urging people to "Vote Nobody" since 2008<ref>{{cite web|url=http://southwalesanarchists.org/ |title=South Wales Anarchists |publisher=South Wales Anarchists |date=2009-05-08 |accessdate=2010-09-01}}</ref> and many other [[anarchism|anarchist]] groups worldwide have promoted similar slogans. * The Landless Peasant Party, which advocates the ownership of land by those who live on it and the replacement of income tax by a flat land tax,<ref name="Landlesspeasants.org">{{cite web |url=http://landlesspeasants.org/?p=158 |title=Election Manifesto 2010 / Landless Peasant Party |publisher=Landlesspeasants.org |date=2010-04-12 |accessdate=2010-09-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100712004008/http://landlesspeasants.org/?p=158 |archivedate=12 July 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> and whose leader Derek Jackson gained publicity for standing against then- Prime Minister Gordon Brown in his home constituency in the 2010 elections,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metro.co.uk/news/election/825018-the-man-with-his-fist-up-behind-gordon-brown-becomes-a-facebook-hit |title=General Election 2010: Derek Jackson, the man with his fist up behind Gordon Brown, becomes a Facebook hit |publisher=Metro.co.uk |date=2010-05-07 |accessdate=2010-09-01}}</ref> include a pledge to add a "None of the above" option to the ballot in all UK elections.<ref name="Landlesspeasants.org"/>
==Canada== No electoral jurisdiction in Canada formally lists "none of the above" as a ballot option. However, in some provincial elections it is effectively possible to vote for "none of the above", by attending the polling station and formally "declining to vote".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arpacanada.ca/index.php/issuesresearch/canadian-politics/111-voting-for-none-of-the-above |title=Voting for none of the above |publisher=Arpacanada.ca |date=2007-11-08 |accessdate=2016-05-07}}</ref> These declined votes are actually counted and become part of the electoral record.
A businessman in [[Prince George, British Columbia|Prince George]], [[British Columbia]] ran in the [[Canadian federal election, 1997|1997 federal election]] in the district of [[Prince George—Bulkley Valley]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www2.parl.gc.ca/Sites/LOP/HFER/hfer.asp?Language=E&Search=Gres&genElection=36&ridProvince=2&submit1=Search |title=History of Federal Ridings since 1867 |website=Parl.gc.ca |date= |accessdate=2016-05-07}}</ref> under the name Zznoneoff, Thea Bove (Thea Bove Zznoneoff); ballots listing candidates alphabetically by surname, he appeared at the bottom. He came sixth of seven candidates with 0.977 percent of votes cast.
A resident of [[Oshawa]], [[Ontario]], formerly known as Sheldon Bergson, has legally changed his name to "Above Znoneofthe",<ref>[http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/toronto/vote-none-of-the-above-byelection-1.3426783 "Voters can pick 'none of the above' thanks to this Whitby-Oshawa byelection candidate"]. [[CBC News]] Toronto, January 29, 2016.</ref> and has registered under that name as a candidate in several provincial and federal [[by-election]]s, most recently the [[By-elections to the 42nd Canadian Parliament#Markham.E2.80.94Thornhill|Markham—Thornhill]] by-election of March 3, 2017. His name order was chosen so that his name would always appear at the bottom of the ballot as "Znoneofthe, Above", although this only works federally as provincial election ballots do not list the candidates in surname order.<ref>[http://news.nationalpost.com/news/canada/canadian-politics/meet-above-znoneofthe-the-fringe-candidate-who-keeps-running-in-ontario-by-elections "Meet Above Znoneofthe, the fringe candidate who keeps running in Ontario by-elections"]. ''[[National Post]]'', November 21, 2016.</ref>
In Ontario, the [[None of the Above Party of Ontario]] is a registered political party, although its stated mandate is for its candidates to serve in the legislature as [[independent (politics)|independent]] representatives who reflect the views and interests of their constituents, rather than simply as a "reject all of the candidates" placeholder.
==Norway== The Norwegian election regulation makes it mandatory to present voters with blank ballots in addition to all of the approved parties and election lists. In the [[Norwegian parliamentary election, 2013|parliamentary election of 2013]], 12874 votes, which is 0.45% of the total votes given, were blank.
==None of the Above candidates and parties in other countries== * In [[Serbia]], None of the above (Ниједан од понуђених одговора, НОПО) is a parliamentary political party, legally formed in 2010, which was mostly popularized on [[Facebook]] and less on other social networking websites. In [[Serbian parliamentary election, 2012]] they received 22,905 votes, and thus won one seat in the [[National Assembly of Serbia]]. * Geoff Richardson changed his full name to "Of The Above None" and stood as an independent for the seat of [[Division of Gilmore|Gilmore]] at the [[Australian federal election, 2007|2007 Australian federal election]]. His name appeared as NONE, Of the Above on the ballot.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.noneoftheabove.com.au/about.htm |title=About |publisher=None Of The Above |date=2007-03-16 |accessdate=2010-09-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110218052948/http://noneoftheabove.com.au/about.htm |archivedate=18 February 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> * In [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2010]], a candidate Vasiliy Humeniuk changed his name to [[Vasily Protyvsih]] (Vasily Against-all). "Against all candidates" is the name of the "none of the above" vote used in Russia and Ukraine.<ref name=Pres>[http://www.interfax.com.ua/eng/main/24082/ CEC registers two more candidates for Ukraine's president] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091109000658/http://www.interfax.com.ua/eng/main/24082/ |date=9 November 2009 }}, [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (November 6, 2009)</ref><ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/53257/ Three candidates united by disgust with authorities], [[Kyiv Post]] (November 19, 2009)</ref> * In 2000, [[Michael Moore]] advocated a [[write-in candidate]] '''Ficus (the plant) for Congress''' as a unified vote for ''none of the above'' in congressional seats where the incumbent was running unopposed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.commondreams.org/news2000/0426-09.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=29 January 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080119080414/http://www.commondreams.org/news2000/0426-09.htm |archivedate=19 January 2008 }}</ref> * David Gatchell of [[Tennessee]] ran for [[Tennessee gubernatorial election, 2002|governor in 2002]] and for [[Tennessee United States Senate election, 2006|Senate in 2006]] as a protest, officially changing his middle name from Leroy to None of the Above.<ref>[http://tennessean.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20060720/NEWS0206/607200385]{{Dead link|date=September 2010}}</ref> In 2006, he got 3,738 votes (0.2 percent). * For the [[Pakistani general election, 2013|2013 Pakistani general election]], the [[Election Commission of Pakistan]] unilaterally decided that a 'none of the above' box would be available as a voting option on ballot papers.<ref name="tribune" /> However, they subsequently decided against it owing to the short amount of time remaining till the elections.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/531463/ecp-decides-against-introducing-none-of-the-above-vote/ |title=ECP decides against introducing 'none of the above' vote - The Express Tribune |publisher=Tribune.com.pk |date=2013-04-05 |accessdate=2016-05-07}}</ref> The concept was suggested to the Election Commission by Abid Hassan Manto, a constitutional expert and a senior lawyer of the Supreme Court of Pakistan.<ref>{{cite news|title=Effective legislation proposed to ensure transparency in general elections|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/498106/effective-legislation-proposed-to-ensure-transparency-in-general-elections/|accessdate=23 January 2013|newspaper=Express Tribune|date=January 23, 2013}}</ref> * [[Elections in South Ossetia]] have an "against all" option.
==Procedures that function like "none of the above"== Most ballots do not have a formal "none of the above" option, but do have procedures that work in a similar way.
=== Argentina ===
In Argentina casting an envelope without a ballot in a [[ballot box]] counts as a blank vote.
===Poland=== In [[Polish legislative election, 1989|1989 legislative election in Poland]] voters were able to vote against the only candidate running, often from the ruling [[Polish United Workers' Party]] by crossing out the candidate's name on the ballot.<ref name=JFund>{{cite news|last=Fund|first=John|title='None of the Above' Should Be on the Ballot|url=http://www.nationalreview.com/articles/316376/none-above-should-be-ballot-john-fund|accessdate=12 September 2012|newspaper=National Review|date=September 10, 2012}}</ref> As a result, voters defeated the sitting prime minister and dozens of leading Communists because they failed to get the required majority.<ref name=JFund />
===Re-open Nominations (RON)=== Many students' unions in [[United Kingdom|Britain]], [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]], and others<ref>{{cite web|author=Martin Hoscik |url=http://www.mayorwatch.co.uk/caroline-pidgeon-named-as-sole-liberal-democrat-mayoral-hopeful/ |title=Caroline Pidgeon named as sole Liberal Democrat mayoral hopeful — MayorWatch |publisher=Mayorwatch.co.uk |date=2015-08-19 |accessdate=2016-05-07}}</ref> use a similar ballot option called 're-open nominations' (RON)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mvcwestsussex.org.uk/glossary.html#RON |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060921194115/http://www.mvcwestsussex.org.uk/glossary.html#RON |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2006-09-21 |title=Make Votes Count In West Sussex |publisher=Mvcwestsussex.org.uk |date=2006-03-20 |accessdate=2010-09-01 }}</ref> in [[instant-runoff voting|IRV]] and [[single transferable vote]] (STV) elections. These include the [[National Union of Students (United Kingdom)|National Union of Students]] in the [[United Kingdom|UK]] and [[University College Dublin Students' Union|UCD Student's Union]] in [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]]. The difference is that RON is a vote against all candidates in FPTP ([[plurality voting system|first-past-the-post]]) and all subsequent candidates in an IRV or STV election.
RON is not strictly a '''none of the above''' candidate in transferable vote elections, as when RON is eliminated during the count its votes are transferred to other candidates if those preferences exist.
===Illegal ballots in ''Robert's Rules of Order''=== The American ''[[Robert's Rules of Order|Robert's Rules of Order, Newly Revised (RONR)]]'' describes various forms of illegal ballots, which are ballots which do not count for any candidate. Blanks are treated as "scrap paper", and are of no effect, but "unintelligible ballots or ballots cast for an unidentifiable candidate or a fictional character are treated as illegal votes. All illegal votes cast by legal voters… are taken into account in determining the number of votes cast for purposes of computing the majority." RONR always requires a majority for election; thus, casting an illegal ballot or one for a hopeless candidate, whether on the ballot or as a write-in, is equivalent to voting No for all other candidates. "The principle is that a choice has no mandate from the voting body unless approval is expressed by more than half of those entitled to vote and registering any evidence of having some opinion."<ref>{{cite parl |title= RONR|edition= 11th|year= 2011|pages= 415-416}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.robertsrules.com/interp_list.html#2006_5 |title= RONR Official Interpretations: 2006-5: Ballot Elections: Voting "No" or "None of the Above" |date= |access-date= |website= The Official Robert's Rules of Order Web Site |publisher= The Robert's Rules Association}}</ref>
==Cultural references== * In the film ''[[Brewster's Millions (1985 film)|Brewster's Millions]],'' the protagonist Brewster (played by [[Richard Pryor]]) is required, under certain conditions, to spend 30 million dollars in 30 days. He joins the race for Mayor of [[New York City]] and throws most of his money at a protest campaign urging a vote for None of the Above. The two major candidates sue Brewster for his confrontational rhetoric, leading to a massive settlement which of course furthers their competitor's goal. Brewster is forced to end his campaign when he learns that he is leading in the polls as a write-in candidate and has to publicly announce that he if he won the mayoralty he wants to decline it but is surprised his "None of the Above" campaign became so popular. Neither candidate wins the election, and a new election with different candidates must be held. * In the sixth-season episode of ''[[Captain Planet and the Planeteers|Captain Planet]]'' called "Dirty Politics" three of the Eco-Villains are running for president and kidnap the fourth candidate, who is the most popular. Despite this over seventy percent vote None of the Above resulting in the need for a new election. * [[L. Neil Smith]]'s novel ''[[The Probability Broach]]'' has an [[alternate history]] in which the [[United States]] becomes a [[Libertarianism|libertarian]] state after a successful [[Whiskey Rebellion]] and the overthrowing and execution of [[George Washington]] by firing squad for treason in 1794, where None of the Above (which is always an option on the ballot){{page needed|date=November 2016}} has received the most votes for President of the [[North American Confederacy]] on two occasions. The first time was in [[United States presidential election, 1968|1968]], defeating Lucy Kropotkin and would serve until 1972 as the NAC's 24th President. The second time was in [[United States presidential election, 2000|2000]] and again in [[United States presidential election, 2004|2004]] and being elected "President for Life" in [[United States presidential election, 2008|2008]], serving as the 28th President. * [[Wavy Gravy]] has run a "[[Nobody for President]]" campaign during several different election years in the United States.

{{Use Australian English|date=May 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2018}} {{Infobox court case | name=Nudd v Taylor | court=[[Supreme Court of Queensland]] | date decided=30 August 2000 | full name=Nudd v Taylor | citations=[http://archive.sclqld.org.au/qjudgment/2000/QSC00-344.pdf [2000] QSC 344] | judges=[[Catherine Holmes|Holmes J]] | prior actions= | subsequent actions= | opinions= }} '''''Nudd v Taylor''''',''Nudd v Taylor'' [http://archive.sclqld.org.au/qjudgment/2000/QSC00-489.pdf [2000] QSC 489] (30 August 2000) [[Supreme Court of Queensland|Supreme Court]] (Qld, Australia). was a [[court]] [[legal case|case]], decided in the [[Supreme Court of Queensland]] on 30 August 2000. The case concerned [[Conflict of laws|Australian Private International Law]], specifically giving a [[Queensland]] authority to the application of the [[Mozambique rule|Moçambique rule]]. ==Facts==
[1] The plaintiff and defendant in this matter lived in a de facto relationship for a number of years. The plaintiff has sought declarations of constructive trust in respect of a number of properties in Queensland, as well as a sum of money which is said to have been a loan to the defendant. The defendant has brought a counterclaim in which she seeks a declaration that she is entitled to a proportion of the proceeds of sale of property situated in California, as well as an accounting in relation to other monies, and damages. [2] In response the plaintiff has filed a conditional notice of intention to defend, disputing the court's jurisdiction to entertain the counterclaim. By the present application he sought a declaration under Rule 16 of the Uniform Civil Procedures Rules to the effect that there is no jurisdiction in the court to deal with the causes of action pleaded in the counterclaim. Upon the hearing of the application, however, the plaintiff's counsel, Mr Taylor, confined his submissions to the claim in respect of the proceeds of sale of the Californian properties, and couched the relief sought in terms of striking out of the relevant paragraphs, rather than seeking a declaration. [3] For the purposes of the present application, the following was common ground. The parties lived together for some seventeen years in the course of the 1980s and 1990s. A number of properties were purchased in Queensland in the name of the defendant. In 1987 they moved to the United States. From 1992 properties were acquired in California. Each of them has been sold. The plaintiff continues to reside in California, while the defendant is resident in New Zealand..
==Judgement== [[Catherine Holmes|Holmes J]] in determining whether there could be an exception to the ''Moçambique'' rule applied in regard to the counterclaim, stated:
[15] In the present case, the defendant's claim to a share of the proceeds of sale of the properties in California depends entirely on her ability to demonstrate a beneficial interest in the properties. The outcome of her counterclaim must depend on how that question is determined. Her claim is, in my view, properly described as one which essentially concerns her right to an interest in the properties as the gravamen of her claim. Accordingly, it becomes necessary to consider whether the second exception applies. Clearly enough, the claim involves the assertion of an equitable obligation of a kind which courts have been prepared to enforce notwithstanding a connection with foreign immovables; but what of the situation when the party against whom the obligation is asserted is not within the jurisdiction?
Holmes J in determining that a foreign litigant had submitted himself to this jurisdiction stated:
[21] It is too broad a statement to say that a foreign plaintiff who proceeds in Queensland thereby submits himself to the court's jurisdiction at large. The position, is, in my respect view, correctly stated by Holland J in ''National Commercial Bank v Wimborne'':''National Commercial Bank v Wimborne'' (1979) 11 [[NSW Law Reports|NSWLR]] 156 (31 December 1979), [[New South Wales Supreme Court|Supreme Court]] (NSW, Australia). {{cquote|a foreign plaintiff, not otherwise subject to the jurisdiction of the court, who brings an action in the Court submits himself by {{sic|ecessary}} implication to every matter of counter-claim that would operate as a defence to his action or that would as a set off or cross claim arising out of the same subject matter reduce or extinguish the plaintiffs' claim; and also, at least if he is not a foreign Sovereign, to a counterclaim founded on or directly arising out of the same subject matter as the plaintiffs' claim that would require to be tried in order to do justice between the parties in relation to that subject matter even if it might result in a judgment against the plaintiff on the counterclaim. His Honour continued, To what has the plaintiff submitted? The answer to that lies, I think, in a consideration of what the plaintiff has brought to the Court for adjudication. He could not, in my opinion, properly be said to have submitted to claims outside of and independent of the subject matter of his own action.''National Commercial Bank v Wimborne'' (1979) 11 [[NSW Law Reports|NSWLR]] 156 at 174.}}
That case was cited with approval by the New South Wales Court of Appeal in ''Marlborough Harbour Board v Charter Travel Co Ltd''.''Marlborough Harbour Board v Charter Travel Co Ltd'' (1989) 18 [[NSW Law Reports|NSWLR]] 223 (1 January 1989), [[New South Wales Court of Appeal|Court of Appeal]] (NSW, Australia). In the latter case, the court was prepared to go somewhat further, deciding that the foreign plaintiff's submission to the jurisdiction extended to a counterclaim which raised a new cause of action, provided that such a cross-claim was founded on or directly arose out of the same subject matter as that of the action. To similar effect, the English Court of Appeal in ''Republic of Liberia v Gulf Oceanic Inc''''Republic of Liberia v Gulf Oceanic'' (1985) 1 Lloyds Rep 539. concluded that a plaintiff submitted himself to the incidents of his litigation, including liability to a counterclaim properly brought. In that case the plaintiffs had sought a declaration in relation to a contract for the purchase of oil and a resulting arbitration. The defendant's counterclaim for damages for breach of the same contract and tort for wrongful procuring of the breach was permitted to stand, notwithstanding that the foreign defendants could not, in the absence of their own litigation, have been made amenable to the jurisdiction of the court on such an action. ==See also== ===Cases Referring to this Case=== * ''AFS Freight Management Pty Ltd v Ziegler Nederland BV''.''AFS Freight Management Pty Ltd v Ziegler Nederland BV'' [http://archive.sclqld.org.au/qjudgment/2000/QSC00-489.pdf [2000] QSC 489] (22 December 2000) [[Supreme Court of Queensland|Supreme Court]] (Qld, Australia). (Applied) ===Cases Considered by this Case=== ;Australia * ''[[Potter v Broken Hill Proprietary Company Ltd]]''.{{cite AustLII|HCA|88|1906|litigants=[[Potter v Broken Hill Pty Co Ltd]] |parallelcite=[http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/cases/cth/HCA/1906/88.pdf (1906) 3 CLR 479] |date=20 March 1906 |courtname=auto}} (Cited) ;United Kingdom * [[Mozambique rule|''British South Africa Co v Companhia de Moçambique'']].''[[British South Africa Co v Companhia de Moçambique]]'' [1893] {{abbr|AC|Appeal Cases}} 602, [[Judicial functions of the House of Lords|House of Lords]], (England and Wales). (Considered) == References == {{Reflist|30em}} [[Category:Conflict of laws case law]]

The following [[Outline (list)|outline]] is provided as an overview of and topical guide to United States federal Indian law and policy:

'''[[Federal Indian policy]]''' – establishes the relationship between the United States Government and the Indian Tribes within its borders. The Constitution gives the federal government primary responsibility for dealing with tribes. Law and U.S. public policy related to [[Native Americans in the United States|Native Americans]] have evolved continuously since the founding of the [[United States]]. David R. Wrone argues that the failure of the treaty system was because of the inability of an individualistic, democratic society to recognize group rights or the value of an organic, corporatist culture represented by the tribes.<ref>David R. Wrone, "Indian Treaties and the Democratic Idea," ''Wisconsin Magazine of History'' (1986) 70#2 pp 83-106</ref>

==Treaties==
[[File:Indiana Indian treaties.svg|thumb|right|250px|Indiana Indian treaties]]
The federal government was in charge of relations with the Indians, and the procedure was to use the treaty making power of the president and the Senate to make formal arrangements. Over 200 treaties were agreed upon by 1840.  Gatlin argues that treaties established a procedure that benefited both parties.  The federal government was primarily interested in guaranteeing that Indian lands did not fall into private hands, and that it handled all negotiations with the tribes.  These negotiations, says Gatlin, strengthened the tribes sense of unity and leadership.  The land sales gave the Indians a steady flow of income, and guarantees of federal financial, medical, and educational aid.<ref>Jay Gatlin, Private Diplomacy to Private Property: States, Tribes and Nations in the Early National Period," ''Diplomatic History '' (1998) 22:1 pp 85-99</ref>

Many of the treaties remain in effect and are of special importance regarding federal recognition of tribal status, hunting and fishing rights, rights to protection of sacred properties, rights to water and minerals, and land claims.<ref>Alexandra Harmon, ed., ''The Power of Promises: Rethinking Indian Treaties in the Pacific Northwest'' (2008)</ref><ref>Charles E. Cleland, ''Faith in Paper: The Ethnohistory and Litigation of Upper Great Lakes Indian Treaties'' (2011) [https://www.amazon.com/Faith-Paper-Ethnohistory-Litigation-Treaties/dp/0472117297/  excerpt and text search]</ref> The federal courts have a long, continuous history of litigation on these issues. The Supreme Court endorsed the procedure, with over 300 decisions making reference to Indian treaties after 1799.<ref>Charles D. Bernholz,  "American Indian treaties and the Supreme Court: A guide to treaty citations from opinions of the United States Supreme Court," ''Journal of Government Information'' (2004) 30#2/3  pp 318-431</ref>

* [[Charmaine White Face]] ([[Oglala Lakota]]), spokesperson for the Teton Sioux Nation Treaty Council and coordinator of the [[Defenders of the Black Hills]], which works toward the Fort Laramie Treaties of [[Treaty of Fort Laramie (1851)|1851]] and [[Treaty of Fort Laramie (1868)|1868]] being enforced. She works in language preservation, land reclamation, and international indigenous human rights.
* [[Bernie Whitebear]] ([[Confederated Tribes of the Colville Reservation|Colville]]), American Indian activist, a co-founder of the Seattle Indian Health Board (SIHB), the United Indians of All Tribes Foundation, and the Daybreak Star Cultural Center.
* [[Robert A. Williams, Jr.]], an American lawyer who is a notable author and legal scholar in the field of Federal Indian Law, International Law and Indigenous Peoples Rights, and Critical Race and Post Colonial Theory.
* [[Sarah Winnemucca]] ([[Northern Paiute]], 1844–1891), author and lecturer who educated non-natives about conditions in Indian Country and founded a school for native children
*[[Zitkala-Sa]] (Gertrude Simmons Bonnin, [[Yankton Dakota]], 1876–1938), political writer and educator, religious freedom activist

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} The '''Paris Convention for the Protection of Industrial Property''', signed in [[Paris]], [[France]], on 20 March 1883, was one of the first [[intellectual property]] [[treaty|treaties]]. It established a Union for the protection of industrial property. The Convention is currently still in force. The substantive provisions of the Convention fall into three main categories: national treatment, [[priority right]] and common rules.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wipo.int/treaties/en/ip/paris/summary_paris.html |title=Summary of the Paris Convention |publisher=WIPO |accessdate=2014-12-06}}</ref>
== Contents == {{more citations needed|section|date=March 2017}}
=== National treatment === According to Articles 2 and 3 of this treaty, juristic and natural persons who are either national of or domiciled in a state party to the Convention shall, as regards the protection of industrial property, enjoy in all the other countries of the Union, the advantages that their respective laws grant to nationals.
In other words, when an applicant files an application for a patent or a trademark in a foreign country member of the Union, the application receives the same treatment as if it came from a national of this foreign country. Furthermore, if the intellectual property right is granted (e.g. if the applicant becomes owners of a patent or of a registered trademark), the owner benefits from the same protection and the same legal remedy against any infringement as if the owner was a national owner of this right.
=== Priority right === The "''Convention priority right''", also called "''Paris Convention priority right''" or "''Union priority right''", was also established by Article 4 of the Paris Convention, and is regarded as one of the cornerstones of the Paris Convention.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.epo.org/law-practice/case-law-appeals/recent/t010015ep1.html|title=Decision T 15/01 (Mystery Swine Disease/SDLO) of 17 June 2004 of Board of Appeal 3.3.01 of the European Patent Office (EPO)|year=2004|at=Reasons for the decision, point 32|quote=The right of priority is generally regarded as one of the cornerstones of the Paris Convention (...)|publisher=European Patent Office|accessdate=30 December 2016}}</ref> It provides that an applicant from one contracting State shall be able to use its first filing date (in one of the contracting State) as the effective filing date in another contracting State, provided that the applicant, or his successor in title, files a subsequent application within 6 months (for [[industrial design]]s and trademarks) or 12 months (for patents and [[utility model]]s) from the first filing.
=== Temporary protection for goods shown at some international exhibitions=== Article 11(1) of the Paris Convention requires that the Countries of the Union "grant temporary protection to patentable inventions, utility models, industrial designs, and trademarks, in respect of goods exhibited at official or officially recognized [[international exhibitions]] held in the territory of any of them".<ref>[http://www.wipo.int/wipolex/en/treaties/text.jsp?file_id=288514#P223_37281 Article 11(1) of the Paris Convention]</ref>
If a patent or trademark registration is applied for during the temporary period of protection, the priority date of the application may be counted "from the date of introduction of the goods into the exhibition" rather than from the date of filing of the application, if the temporary protection referred to in Article 11(1) has been implemented in such a manner in national law.<ref>[http://www.wipo.int/wipolex/en/treaties/text.jsp?file_id=288514#P223_37281 Article 11(2) of the Paris Convention]</ref><ref name="Bodenhausen-p150">{{cite book|last=Bodenhausen|first=G.H.C.|authorlink=Georg Bodenhausen|title=Guide to the Application of the Paris Convention for the Protection of Industrial Property As Revised at Stockholm in 1967|url=http://www.wipo.int/freepublications/en/intproperty/611/wipo_pub_611.pdf|accessdate=28 December 2016|year=1969|publisher=United International Bureaux for the Protection of Intellectual Property (BIRPI)|page=150|isbn=92-805-0368-5}}</ref> There are, however, other means for the Countries of the Union to implement in their national law the temporary protection provided for in Article 11 of the Paris Convention:
{{quote|It is also possible, for example, in the case of exhibited patentable inventions, to make provision for temporary protection by other means, namely, by prescribing that, during a certain period, such exhibition will not destroy the [[novelty (patent)|novelty]] of the invention and that the person who exhibits the invention will also be protected against usurpation of his invention by third parties. Still another possibility of protection consists in the recognition of a [[right of prior use]] in favor of the exhibitor as against possible rights acquired by third parties.<ref name="Bodenhausen-p150"/>}}
=== Mutual independence of patents and trademarks in the different Countries of the Union=== According to Articles 4bis and 6 (for patents and trademarks respectively), for foreigners, the application for a patent or the registration of a trademark shall be determined by the member state in accordance with their national law and not by the decision of the country of origin or any other countries. Patent applications and trademark registrations are independent among contracting countries.
== History == After a diplomatic conference in Paris in 1880, the Convention was signed in 1883 by 11 countries: Belgium, Brazil, France, Guatemala, Italy, the Netherlands, Portugal, El Salvador, Serbia, Spain and Switzerland. Guatemala, El Salvador and Serbia denounced and reapplied the convention via accession.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wipo.int/treaties/en/ShowResults.jsp?country_id=ALL&start_year=ANY&end_year=ANY&search_what=C&treaty_id=2 |title=Contracting Parties to the Paris Convention |publisher=WIPO |accessdate=2012-12-30}}</ref>
The Treaty was revised at [[Brussels]], Belgium, on 14 December 1900, at [[Washington, DC|Washington]], United States, on 2 June 1911, at [[The Hague]], Netherlands, on 6 November 1925, at London, United Kingdom, on 2 June 1934, at [[Lisbon]], Portugal, on 31 October 1958, and at [[Stockholm]], Sweden, on 14 July 1967, and was amended on 28 September 1979.
== Contracting parties == {{main|List of parties to the Paris Convention for the Protection of Industrial Property}} [[Image:Paris Convention for the Protection of Industrial Property.png|thumb|right|400px|Paris Convention members (in green)]]
As of February 2017, the Convention has 177 contracting member countries,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wipo.int/treaties/en/ShowResults.jsp?lang=en&treaty_id=2 |title=Contracting Parties > Paris Convention (Total Contracting Parties : 177) |publisher=[[World Intellectual Property Organization]] (WIPO) |accessdate=28 February 2017}}</ref> which makes it one of the most widely adopted treaties worldwide. Notably, [[Taiwan]] (officially the Republic of China or ROC) and Burma are not parties to the Convention.
=== Former contracting parties === *[[Austria-Hungary]] (succeeded by Austria and Hungary) *[[Czechoslovakia]] *[[Orange Free State]] 1899–31 May 1902 *[[Colony of Queensland]] (1891–1900, after federation acceded to by Australia) *[[Serbia and Montenegro]] (succeeded by Serbia) *[[Soviet Union]] (succeeded by the Russian Federation) *[[Yugoslavia]] (succeeded by Serbia and Montenegro and then Serbia).
== Administration == The Paris Convention is administered by the [[World Intellectual Property Organization]] (WIPO),<ref>WIPO web site, [http://www.wipo.int/treaties/en/ ''WIPO-Administered Treaties'']. Consulted on 10 August 2007.</ref> based in [[Geneva]], Switzerland.<ref>WIPO web site, [http://www.wipo.int/about-wipo/en/what_is_wipo.html ''What is WIPO?'']. Consulted on 10 August 2007.</ref>
== See also == * [[Agreement on Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights]] (TRIPs) * [[Berne Convention for the Protection of Literary and Artistic Works]] * [[Budapest Treaty]] * [[Convention Establishing the World Intellectual Property Organization]] (WIPO Convention) * [[Patent Cooperation Treaty]] (PCT) * [[Patent Law Treaty]] (PLT) * [[Provisional application|US provisional patent application]] * [[Substantive Patent Law Treaty]] (SPLT) * [[World Intellectual Property Organization]] (WIPO)
== References == {{reflist|30em}}

Heymanns|location=Köln|isbn=3-452-17822-6}}
== External links == *[http://www.wipo.int/treaties/en/ip/paris/index.html Paris Convention] at the [[World Intellectual Property Organization]] (WIPO) *[http://www.bailii.org/ew/cases/EWHC/Patents/2003/430.html ''Haberman v Comptroller''], a UK court decision that helps to understand the concept of priority.

{{Refimprove|date=August 2009}}
[[File:Persecución del Chancho.JPG|250px|thumbnail|Pig wrestling in [[Chile]].]] '''Pig wrestling''' (also known as '''pig scramble'''<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.co.uk/newspapers?id=kqcIAAAAIBAJ&sjid=o0IDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3773,1040222&dq=pig-scramble&hl=en|title=Pig Scramble Is Fun, Profitable|date=22 September 1950|work=Ludington Daily News|accessdate=2009-10-06}}</ref> and with the variants '''hog wrestling''' and '''greased pig catching''') is a type of game sometimes played at [[agricultural show]]s such as [[State fair|state]] and [[county fair]]s, in which contestants, usually children or young adults, try to grab a slippery [[Domestic pig|pig]]. In the most common version of the game, a team of four members chases a domestic pig around a fenced-off [[mud]] pit and attempts to place it in a barrel, in a race against the clock.<ref>[http://www.pinedaleonline.com/news/2005/08/PigWrestlingSublette.htm Pig Wrestling-Sublette County Fair 2005 - Pinedale, Wyoming]</ref> In some events the pigs are [[wikt:grease|grease]]d with vegetable or mineral oil in order to make catching the pig more difficult.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://loudounextra.washingtonpost.com/news/2007/jul/26/greased-pig-scramble-evenings-big-draw/ |title=Greased Pig Scramble Is Evening’s Big Draw |date=26 July 2007 |work=Washington Post |accessdate=2009-11-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081012095002/http://loudounextra.washingtonpost.com/news/2007/jul/26/greased-pig-scramble-evenings-big-draw/ |archivedate=12 October 2008 }}</ref>
==Rules==
Rules vary depending on the venue. Some contests use larger pigs, while others use those that are smaller. Some include a single pig, while others use more than one. The pigs are coated with shortening, vegetable oil, lard, or another lubricant. Contestants chase the pigs around a field or other determined area. Depending on the contest, contestants either try to get one or both hands on the pig, tackle and hold the pig down, or drag the pig to a set point. There may be several rounds per contest. The prize for winning is often the pig itself.<ref name=autogenerated1>[http://www.sptimes.com/2006/09/04/Pasco/Pig_catching_rubs_som.shtml Pasco: Pig catching rubs some the wrong way]</ref>
Children too young to compete in pig wrestling may compete in a greased pig chase, the object of which is to hang onto a greased pig for a certain amount of time. A more juvenile pig is often used for this competition.
==Animal welfare== Concerns have been raised by [[animal rights]] organizations that using pigs in this form of entertainment is inhumane,<ref name=autogenerated1 /><ref>[http://www.wbaltv.com/news/17564782/detail.html Farm Owner, County At Odds Over Pig Wrestling - Baltimore, Maryland News Story - WBAL Baltimore]</ref> since the pigs have no choice in the matter of whether they want to wrestle or not. The wrestling may impose undue emotional stress on the pigs, as evidenced by fearful squealing, and causes physical torsional stress on the pigs' joints. Some fairs have thus eliminated pig wrestling from their events.<ref>[http://www.therecorddelta.com/V2_news_articles.php?heading=0&page=&story_id=1580 The Record Delta County axes greased pig contest]</ref> In [[Minnesota]], pig wrestling is a [[misdemeanor]].<ref>[https://www.revisor.mn.gov/statutes/?id=343.36 Minnesota Statutes 343.36 GREASED PIG CONTESTS AND TURKEY SCRAMBLES]</ref>
==In popular culture== A variant is shown in ''[[The Man in the Iron Mask (1998 film)|The Man in the Iron Mask]]'' in which a pig dressed to look like a unicorn is released with a valuable gem hung around its neck. The first to capture the pig is allowed to keep the treasure.
The television show [[Family Guy]] parodies this concept with the [[List of characters in Family Guy#Citizens of Quahog|Greased-up Deaf Guy]]; a recurring character that first appears in "[[The Thin White Line]]" as the quarry of a company picnic event.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Q5Am4Xc1axA YouTube - Catch the Greased Up Deaf Guy]</ref>
In a 2014 episode of the [[Discovery Channel]] series ''[[MythBusters]]'', the Build Team investigated the difficulty of catching a greased pig, both with and without technological assistance.
==See also== *[[Pig racing]]

page.title: Sham marriage in the United Kingdom

revision.text:
{{POV-check|date=August 2018}} '''Sham marriage in the United Kingdom''' is a form of [[Illegal immigration to the United Kingdom|immigration fraud]] in the UK, primarily London{{Citation needed|date=August 2018}}, conducted systematically to gain [[British nationality law|British citizenship]] in exchange for short-term financial gain. The fraud is often committed by taking advantage of loopholes in [[Immigration to Europe|EU]] [[United Kingdom immigration law|immigration law]] to circumvent customary immigration procedures. The fraud is investigated mostly by the UK [[Border Force]] and previously by the UK Border Agency.
[[File:Oxford sham marriage - Would-be-bride leaves Oxford register office1.jpg|thumb|right|Sham marriage on 8 June 2010 at Oxford Registry Office]]
==Marriage law in the UK== The laws applying to British citizenship are the same across all four constituent countries, and are under European Union law; however, the [[Marriage law|laws of marriage]] are not the same across all four constituent countries.
==History== In 2010 a legal ruling{{What ruling?}} by the [[European Court of Human Rights]] (ECHR), which administers the [[European Convention on Human Rights]], assisted the incidence of sham marriage in the UK {{Citation needed|date=August 2018}}. Increases in sham marriage were reported in London boroughs such as [[London Borough of Wandsworth|Wandsworth]] <ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8444360.stm January 2010 report]</ref>. Before 2010, people would need a marriage visa from their own country of origin.
[[File:Raid Sham marriage offenders taken away.jpg|thumb|right|Offenders are caught in June 2010; the [[wedding reception]] would have to later recommence at the police station]]
==Containment== Sham marriage in the UK is also investigated, as a whole phenomenon, by [[MigrationWatch UK]].<ref>[https://www.migrationwatchuk.org/pdfs/BP8_38.pdf MigrationWatch UK July 2010]</ref> The whole phenomenon is the responsibility of [[UK Visas and Immigration]]. The [[Immigration Act 2014]] included language concerning bogus marriages{{Citation needed|date=August 2018}}, and sham marriage was also referenced by Section 24 of the [[Immigration and Asylum Act 1999]].
==See also== * [[Bogus colleges in the United Kingdom]] * [[Legal consequences of marriage and civil partnership in England and Wales]] * [[Marriage in the United Kingdom]] * [[National Border Targeting Centre]]

(1848). {{Google books|KBQEAAAAQAAJ|''Chinas handel: industri och Statsforfattning,'' p. 22.|page=22}} The treaty was negotiated in March 1847 by [[Carl Fredrik Liljevalch, Sr.|Carl Fredrik Liljevalch]] and [[Qiying]], the [[Viceroy of Liangguang]],Hofbert, Herman ''et al.'' (1906). "Liljewalch, Carl Fredrik" [http://runeberg.org/sbh/b0055.html ''Svenskt biografiskt handlexikon,'' Vol. II, p. 55]; retrieved 2011-07-15 and was one of the [[unequal treaties]] between Western powers and China that followed the [[First Opium War]]. The treaty was actually never ratified by Chinese representatives, which cast a shadow over the legality of the outcome, but nevertheless went into effect, lasting the following 60 years.Cassel, Pär. ''Traktaten som aldrig var och fördraget som nästan inte blev - De svensk-norsk–kinesiska förbindelserna 1847–1909*'' ==Provisions== Its terms, similar to the 1844 [[Treaty of Wanghia]] between the [[United States]] and China, provided that Sweden-Norway would have the same privileges in China as other treaty powers, so-called [[most-favored-nation]] status.Tai, En-Sai. (1918). {{Google books|TlAH9CGEdPcC|''Treaty ports in China (a study in diplomacy),'' p. 161.|page=161}} Like the United States and [[British Empire]] before it, commercial access was granted to the five [[treaty port]]s of [[Guangzhou|Canton]] (Kwangchow), [[Amoy]], [[Fuzhou]], [[Ningbo]] and [[Shanghai]]. This was in stark contrast to previous Western relations with China, when only Canton was open for foreign trade.
Like other Western countries, extraterritorial rights was given to Sweden-Norway; jurisdiction over citizens of Sweden and Norway in the treaty ports was transferred from China to Sweden-Norway. The treaty furthermore allowed Sweden-Norway to send consuls to China, and to have its commerce being subjected to fixed tariffs only. The provisions of the treaty remained in force until the twentieth century, with a new treaty being negotiated in 1908 by Gustav Oscar Wallenberg, three years after the [[Dissolution of the union between Norway and Sweden in 1905|dissolution of Sweden-Norway]].{{Cite journal | doi = 10.2307/2212084 | jstor = 2212084 | title = Treaty of Amity, Commerce and Navigation, between Sweden and China, Signed at Peking, July 2, 1908, with the Additional Article Signed at Peking May 24, 1909 | journal = The American Journal of International Law | volume = 4 | issue = 4 | pages = 337 | year = 1910 }} ==See also== * [[Unequal treaties]] * [[Treaty port]] ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References== * Hofbert, Herman ''et al.''
